depth 2":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/nu12061583","date":"2020-05-25","title":"Effects of COVID-19 Home Confinement on Eating Behaviour and Physical Activity: Results of the ECLB-COVID19 International Online Survey","abstract":"Background: Public health recommendations and governmental measures during the COVID-19 pandemic have resulted in numerous restrictions on daily living including social distancing, isolation and home confinement.\n While these measures are imperative to abate the spreading of COVID-19, the impact of these restrictions on health behaviours and lifestyles at home is undefined.\n Therefore, an international online survey was launched in April 2020, in seven languages, to elucidate the behavioural and lifestyle consequences of COVID-19 restrictions.\n This report presents the results from the first thousand responders on physical activity (PA) and nutrition behaviours.\n Methods: Following a structured review of the literature, the Effects of home Confinement on multiple Lifestyle Behaviours during the COVID-19 outbreak (ECLB-COVID19) Electronic survey was designed by a steering group of multidisciplinary scientists and academics.\n The survey was uploaded and shared on the Google online survey platform.\n Thirty-five research organisations from Europe, North-Africa, Western Asia and the Americas promoted the survey in English, German, French, Arabic, Spanish, Portuguese and Slovenian languages.\n Questions were presented in a differential format, with questions related to responses before and during confinement conditions.\n Results: 1047 replies (54% women) from Asia (36%), Africa (40%), Europe (21%) and other (3%) were included in the analysis.\n The COVID-19 home confinement had a negative effect on all PA intensity levels (vigorous, moderate, walking and overall).\n Additionally, daily sitting time increased from 5 to 8 h per day.\n Food consumption and meal patterns (the type of food, eating out of control, snacks between meals, number of main meals) were more unhealthy during confinement, with only alcohol binge drinking decreasing significantly.\n Conclusion: While isolation is a necessary measure to protect public health, results indicate that it alters physical activity and eating behaviours in a health compromising direction.\n A more detailed analysis of survey data will allow for a segregation of these responses in different age groups, countries and other subgroups, which will help develop interventions to mitigate the negative lifestyle behaviours that have manifested during the COVID-19 confinement.\n","id":"PMC7352706","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Achraf","surname":"Ammar","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"Brach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Michael","surname":"Brach","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Khaled","surname":"Trabelsi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hamdi","surname":"Chtourou","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Omar","surname":"Boukhris","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Liwa","surname":"Masmoudi","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bassem","surname":"Bouaziz","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Ellen","surname":"Bentlage","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Daniella","surname":"How","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mona","surname":"Ahmed","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Mona","surname":"Ahmed","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Patrick","surname":"Müller","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Notger","surname":"Müller","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"Asma","surname":"Aloui","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Omar","surname":"Hammouda","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Laisa time in children is not only due to screen media use: a cross-sectional study","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Sedentary behaviour has become a growing public health concern.\n\n Currently, it is a common belief that screen time (SCT) is a key factor in high overall sedentary time (ST) and is often used as a primary outcome.\n\n However, the evidence is lacking.\n\n Therefore, this study investigated the association of objectively assessed total ST with SCT among children.\n\n Further, SCT was investigated separately for sedentary level, weight status, gender, and migration background.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>For 198 primary school children (7.1?±?0.7?years, boys: 43.9%) ST was assessed objectively using a multi-sensor device (Actiheart®; CamNtech, Cambridge, UK).\n\n The sample was split into three groups (tertiles) to investigate SCT of children with low, medium and high ST.\n\n SCT and socio-demographic parameters, such as migration background, were assessed using a parental questionnaire; anthropometric data was collected at schools.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Absolut SCT did not differ significantly among the three sedentary groups: Daily average of SCT was 83.8?±?55.0?min (27.4% of ST) for children with high ST, 82.8?±?50.5?min (39.8% of ST) for children with medium ST, and 77.2?±?59.4?min (71.3% of ST) for those with low ST.\n\n However, relatively the SCT percentage of total ST was significantly higher among children with low ST (p?&lt;?0.01).\n\n Significantly higher SCT was found in children with migration background (p?&lt;?0.01), while underweight children had significantly less SCT (p?&lt;?0.05).\n\n An association of total SCT and overall ST was found for the whole sample (B?=?17.11, [2.75; 31.48], p?=?0.02), but did not remain when analysis were separated for the groups, except for normal weight children (B?=?15.97, [0.13; 31.81], p?=?0.05).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>The amount of SCT is the same among high, low and medium sedentary children, and high ST is largely independent of SCT.\n\n Therefore, SCT cannot be the key contributor to high ST and should not solely be used for predicting or changing childrens sedentary behaviour.\n\n Moreover, childrens weight status to classify activity levels and the role of possible compensation mechanisms should be considered in future research and when trying to intervene on ST.\n\n\nTrial registration\nid='Par5'>German Clinical Trials Register (DRKS), DRKS-ID: DRKS00000494 DATE: found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1007/s11136-016-1454-8","date":"2016-11-04","title":"Evaluating and establishing national norms for mental wellbeing using the short WarwickEdinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (SWEMWBS): findings from the Health Survey for England","abstract":"Purpose\nThe WarwickEdinburgh Mental Well-being Scale (WEMWBS), 14 positively worded statements, is a validated instrument to measure mental wellbeing on a population level.\n\n Less is known about the population distribution of the shorter seven-item version (SWEMWBS) or its performance as an instrument to measure wellbeing.\n\n\nMethods\nUsing the Health Survey for England 20102013 (n = 27,169 adults aged 16+, nationally representative of the population), age- and sex-specific norms were estimated using means and percentiles.\n\n Criterion validity was examined using: (1) Spearman correlations (?) for SWEMWBS with General Health Questionnaire (GHQ-12), happiness index, EQ-VAS (2) a multinomial logit model with SWEMWBS (low, medium and high wellbeing) as the outcome and demographic, social and health behaviours as explanatory variables.\n\n Relative validity was examined by comparing SWEMWBS with WEMWBS using: (1) Spearman correlations (continuous data), and (2) the weighted kappa statistic (categorical), within population subgroups.\n\n\nResults\nMean (median) SWEMWBS was 23.7 (23.2) for men and 23.2 (23.2) for women (p = 0.100).\n\n Spearman correlations were moderately sized for the happiness index (? = 0.53, P &lt; 0.001), GHQ-12 (? = ?0.52, p &lt; 0.001) and EQ-VAS (? = 0.40, p &lt; 0.001).\n\n Participants consuming &lt;1 portion of fruit and vegetables a day versus ?5 (odds ratio = 1.43 95% Confidence Interval = (1.221.66)) and current smokers versus non-smokers (1.28 (1.151.41)) were more likely to have low vs medium wellbeing.\n\n Participants who binge drank versus non-drinkers were less likely to have high versus medium wellbeing (0.81 (0.710.92)).\n\n Spearman correlations between SWEMWBS and WEMWBS were above 0.95; weighted kappa statistics showed almost perfect agreement (0.790.85).\n\n\nConclusion\nSWEMWBS distinguishes mental wellbeing between subgroups, similarly to WEMWBS, but is less sensitive to gender differences.\n\n\nElectronic supplementary material\nThe online version of this article (doi:10.1007/s11136-016-1454-8) contains supplementary material, which is available to authorized users.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5376387","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Springer International Publishing","authors":[{"firstname":"Linda","surname":"Ng Fat","email":"l.ngfat@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Shaun","surname":"Scholes","email":"s.scholes@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sadie","surname":"Boniface","email":"sadie.boniface@kcl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Jennifer","surname":"Mindell","email":"j.mindell@ucl.ac.uk","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Sarah","surname":"Stewart-Brown","email":"sarah.stewart-brown@warwick.ac.uk","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.1002/mpr.1610","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Validation of the Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (MFQ) and Short Mood and Feelings Questionnaire (SMFQ) in New Zealand help-seeking adolescents","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"International Physical Activity Questionnaire: 12-Contry Reliability and Validity","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1479-5868-8-115","date":"2011-10-21","title":"Validity of the international physical activity questionnaire short form (IPAQ-SF): A systematic review","abstract":"Background\nThe International Physical Activity Questionnaire - Short Form (IPAQ-SF) has been recommended as a cost-effective method to assess physical activity.\n\n Several studies validating the IPAQ-SF have been conducted with differing results, but no systematic review of these studies has been reported.\n\n\nMethods\nThe keywords 'IPAQ', 'validation', and 'validity' were searched in PubMed and Scopus.\n\n Studies published in English that validated the IPAQ-SF against an objective physical activity measuring device, doubly labeled water, or an objective fitness measure were included.\n\n\nResults\nTwenty-three validation studies were included in this review.\n\n There was a great deal of variability in the methods used across studies, but the results were largely similar.\n\n Correlations between the total physical activity level measured by the IPAQ-SF and objective standards ranged from 0.09 to 0.39; none reached the minimal acceptable standard in the literature (0.50 for objective activity measuring devices, 0.40 for fitness measures).\n\n Correlations between sections of the IPAQ-SF for vigorous activity or moderate activity level/walking and an objective standard showed even greater variability (-0.18 to 0.76), yet several reached the minimal acceptable standard.\n\n Only six studies provided comparisons between physical activity levels derived from the IPAQ-SF and those obtained from objective criterion.\n\n In most studies the IPAQ-SF overestimated physical activity level by 36 to 173 percent; one study underestimated by 28 percent.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe correlation between the IPAQ-SF and objective measures of activity or fitness in the large majority of studies was lower than the acceptable standard.\n\n Furthermore, the IPAQ-SF typically overestimated physical activity as measured by objective criterion by an average of 84 percent.\n\n the Tunisian case and lessons for global epidemics in the context of 3PM strategies","abstract":"id='Par1'>Covid-19 is neither the first nor the last viral epidemic which societies around the world are, were and will be affected by.\n Which lessons should be taken from the current pandemic situation? The Covid-19 disease is still not well characterised, and many research teams all over the world are working on prediction of the epidemic scenario, protective measures to populations and sub-populations, therapeutic and vaccination issues, amongst others.\n Contextually, countries with currently low numbers of Covid-19-infected individuals such as Tunisia are intended to take lessons from those countries which already reached the exponential phase of the infection distribution as well as from those which have the exponential phase behind them and record a minor number of new cases such as China.\n To this end, in Tunisia, the pandemic wave has started with a significant delay compared with Europe, the main economic partner of the country.\n In this paper, we do analyse the current pandemic situation in this country by studying the infection evolution and considering potential protective strategies to prevent a pandemic scenario.\n The model is predictive based on a large number of undetected Covid-19 cases that is particularly true for some country regions such as Sfax.\n Infection distribution and mortality rate analysis demonstrate a highly heterogeneous picture over the country.\n Qualitative and quantitative comparative analysis leads to a conclusion that the reliable real-time monitoring based on the randomised laboratory tests is the optimal predictive strategy to create the most effective evidence-based preventive measures.\n In contrast, lack of tests may lead to incorrect political decisions causing either unnecessary over-protection of the population that is risky for a long-term economic recession, or under-protection of the population leading to a post-containment pandemic rebound.\n Recommendations are provided in the context of advanced predictive, preventive and personalised (3P) medical approach.\n","id":"PMC7182506","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Springer International Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/S0140-6736(20)30460-8","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The psychological impact of quarantine and how to reduce it: rapid review of the evidence","abstract":"The December, 2019 coronavirus disease outbreak has seen many countries ask people who have potentially come into contact with the infection to isolate themselves at home or in a dedicated quarantine facility.\n Decisions on how to apply quarantine should be based on the best available evidence.\n We did a Review of the psychological impact of quarantine using three electronic databases.\n Of 3166 papers found, 24 are included in this Review.\n Most reviewed studies reported negative psychological effects including post-traumatic stress symptoms, confusion, and anger.\n Stressors included longer quarantine duration, infection fears, frustration, boredom, inadequate supplies, inadequate information, financial loss, and stigma.\n Some researchers have suggested long-lasting effects.\n In situations where quarantine is deemed necessary, officials should quarantine individuals for no longer than required, provide clear rationale for quarantine and information about protocols, and ensure sufficient supplies are provided.\n Appeals to altruism by reminding the public about the benefits of quarantine to wider society can be favourable.\n","id":"PMC7158942","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Elsevier Ltd.","authors":[{"firstname":"Samantha impacts of quarantine during disease outbreaks and interventions that may help to relieve strain","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.4178/epih.e2016048","date":"2016-11-05","title":"Mental health status of people isolated due to Middle East Respiratory Syndrome","abstract":"OBJECTIVES\nIsolation due to the management of infectious diseases is thought to affect mental health, but the effects are still unknown.\n\n We examined the prevalence of anxiety symptoms and anger in persons isolated during the Middle East Respiratory Syndrome (MERS) epidemic both at isolation period and at four to six months after release from isolation.\n\n We also determined risk factors associated with these symptoms at four to six months.\n\n\nMETHODS\nOf 14,992 individuals isolated for 2-week due to having contact with MERS patients in 2015, when MERS was introduced to Korea, 1,692 individuals were included in this study.\n\n Anxiety symptoms were evaluated with the Generalized Anxiety Disorder 7-item scale and anger was assessed with the State-Trait Anger Expression Inventory at four to six months after release from isolation for MERS.\n\n\nRESULTS\nOf 1,692 who came in contact with MERS patients, 1,656 were not diagnosed with MERS.\n\n Among 1,656, anxiety symptoms showed 7.6% (95% confidence interval [CI], 6.3 to 8.9%) and feelings of anger were present in 16.6% (95% CI, 14.8 to 18.4%) during the isolation period.\n\n At four to six months after release from isolation, anxiety symptoms were observed in 3.0% (95%CI, 2.2 to 3.9%).\n\n Feelings of anger were present in 6.4% (95% CI, 5.2 to 7.6%).\n\n Risk factors for experiencing anxiety symptoms and anger at four to six months after release included symptoms related to MERS during isolation, inadequate supplies (food, clothes, accommodation), social networking activities (email, text, Internet), history of psychiatric illnesses, and financial loss.\n\n\nCONCLUSIONS\nMental health problems at four to six month after release from isolation might be prevented by providing mental health support to individuals with vulnerable mental health, and providing accurate information as well as appropriate supplies, including food, clothes, and accommodation.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5177805","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Korean Society of extracellular matrix through its heparin-binding domain.\n Enhanced EcSOD activity prevents oxidative stress and damage, which are fundamental in a variety of disease pathologies.\n In this review we Physical Activity Levels in Australian University Students","abstract":"The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic resulted in physical isolation measures in many parts of the world.\n In Australia, nationwide restrictions included staying at home, unless seeking medical care, providing care, purchasing food, undertaking exercise, or attending work in an essential service.\n All undergraduate university classes transitioned to online, mostly home-based learning.\n We, therefore, examined the effect of isolation measures during the early phase of the COVID-19 pandemic in Australia (March/April) on diet (24-h recall) and physical activity (Active Australia Survey) patterns in third-year biomedical students.\n Findings were compared with students enrolled in the same course in the previous two years.\n In females, but not males, energy intake was ~20% greater during the pandemic, and snacking frequency and energy density of consumed snacks also increased compared with 2018 and 2019. Physical activity was impacted for both sexes during the pandemic with ~30% fewer students achieving sufficient levels of activity, defined by at least 150 min over at least five sessions, compared with the previous two years.\n In a follow-up study six to eight weeks later (1418% response rate), during gradual easing of nationwide restrictions albeit continued gym closures and online learning, higher energy intake in females and reduced physical activity levels in both sexes persisted.\n These data demonstrate the health impacts of isolation measures, with the potential to affect long-term diet and activity behaviours.\n ","id":"PMC7353248","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Linda status","abstract":"id='Par1'>An acute respiratory disease, caused by a novel coronavirus (SARS-CoV-2, previously known as 2019-nCoV), the coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) has spread throughout China and received worldwide attention.\n On 30 January 2020, World Health Organization (WHO) officially declared the COVID-19 epidemic as a public health emergency of international concern.\n The emergence of SARS-CoV-2, since the severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus (SARS-CoV) in 2002 and Middle East respiratory syndrome coronavirus (MERS-CoV) in 2012, marked the third introduction of a highly pathogenic and large-scale epidemic coronavirus into the human population in the twenty-first century.\n As of 1 March 2020, a total of 87,137 confirmed cases globally, 79,968 confirmed in China and 7169 outside of China, with 2977 deaths (3.4%) had been reported by WHO.\n Meanwhile, several independent research groups have identified that SARS-CoV-2 belongs to ?-coronavirus, with highly identical genome to bat coronavirus, pointing to bat as the natural host.\n The novel coronavirus uses the same receptor, angiotensin-converting enzyme 2 (ACE2) as that for SARS-CoV, and mainly spreads through the respiratory tract.\n Importantly, increasingly evidence showed sustained human-to-human transmission, along with many exported cases across the globe.\n The clinical symptoms of COVID-19 patients include fever, cough, fatigue and a small population of patients appeared gastrointestinal infection symptoms.\n The elderly and people with underlying diseases are susceptible to infection and prone to serious outcomes, which may be associated with acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS) and cytokine storm.\n Currently, there are few specific antiviral strategies, but several potent candidates of antivirals and repurposed drugs are under urgent investigation.\n In this review, we summarized the latest research progress of the epidemiology, pathogenesis, and clinical characteristics of COVID-19, and discussed the current treatment and scientific advancements to combat the epidemic novel study was to investigate whether declared sugar restriction is reflected in actual sucrose intake and diet quality of young non-dieting women, with differentiation between the weekend and weekdays.\n restricting sugar (nRS, n = 116).\n Comparisons between groups were made separately for seven days of the week, five weekdays and two weekend days without and with an adjustment for 2000 kcal of energy.\n Relative differences (RD, in %) in mean diet nutritional values between groups were calculated, where RD (%) = (RS ? nRS) × 100/nRS, and were verified with a two-tailed t-test.\n In the seven-day diet of the RS group, in comparison to the nRS group, a lower daily intake of sucrose (by 22%) and MUFA (by 8%) and a higher content of most nutrients (by 738%) was found.\n No significant differences were observed in energy intake between RS and nRS women over the course of seven days, including weekdays and the weekend.\n Daily intake for the weekend, in comparison to weekdays, in RC and nRC women was higher with respect to energy (by 530 and 512 kcal, i.\ne.\n, 37% and 34%, respectively), sucrose (44% and 23%, respectively), and most nutrients (by 1798% and 1642%, respectively).\n However, after the adjustment for 2000 kcal of energy, the daily intake of most nutrients in the weekend was lower (by 630% and 327%, in RS and nRS groups, respectively), than during weekdays.\n The intention to restrict sucrose has improved diet quality by decreasing sucrose intake and increasing the content of most nutrients, but had no effect on energy intake throughout the week.\n The quality of the womens diet during the weekend was compromised, regardless of restricting or not restricting sugar.\n Encouragement to restrict sugar intake throughout the week and control the food intake during the weekend may be an effective strategy for young women to maintain a healthy activity, age, and gender","abstract":"Background\nIn recent years, there has been a decline in physical activity among adults.\n\n Motivation has been shown to be a crucial factor in maintaining physical activity.\n\n The purpose of this study was to examine whether motives for participation could accurately discriminate gender, age, and type of physical activity.\n\n\nMethods\nA quantitative, cross-sectional descriptive research design was employed.\n\n The Physical Activity and Leisure Motivation Scale (PALMS) was used to assess motives for physical activity in 1,360 adults (703 males, 657 females) who had been exercising regularly for at least six months.\n\n The PALMS consists of 40 items that constitute eight sub-scales (mastery, enjoyment, psychological condition, physical condition, appearance, others expectations, affiliation, competition/ego).\n\n Respondents were divided into two age groups (young adults aged 20 to 40 years and middle-aged adults 41 to 64 years) and five types of activity (individual racing sports plus bowls, team sports, racquet sports, martial arts, and exercise).\n\n\nResults\nThe group discriminant function analyses revealed significant canonical functions correctly classifying the cases into gender (82%), age group (83%), team sport players 76%, individual racing sport plus bowls players 91%, racquet sport players 90%, exercisers 84%, and martial art players 91%.\n\n The competition/ego, appearance, physical condition, and mastery sub-scales contributed most to gender differences.\n\n Five sub-scales (mastery, psychological condition, others expectations, affiliation, and enjoyment) contributed most to the discriminant function for age.\n\n For type of activity, different sub-scales were the strongest contributors to the discriminant function for each type of PA.\n\n\nConclusion\nThe findings in this study suggest that strong and important motives for participation in physical activity are different across type of activity, age, and gender in adults.\n\n Understanding the motives that influence physical activity participation is critical for developing interventions to promote higher physical activity, and self-determination theory: A systematic review","abstract":"Background\nMotivation is a critical factor in supporting sustained exercise, which in turn is associated with important health outcomes.\n\n Accordingly, research on exercise motivation from the perspective of self-determination theory (SDT) has grown considerably in recent years.\n\n Previous reviews have been mostly narrative and theoretical.\n\n Aiming at a more comprehensive review of empirical data, this article examines the empirical literature on the relations between key SDT-based constructs and exercise and physical activity behavioral outcomes.\n\n\nMethods\nThis systematic review includes 66 empirical studies published up to June 2011, including experimental, cross-sectional, and prospective studies that have measured exercise causality orientations, autonomy/need support and need satisfaction, exercise motives (or goal contents), and exercise self-regulations and motivation.\n\n We also studied SDT-based interventions aimed at increasing exercise behavior.\n\n In all studies, actual or self-reported exercise/physical activity, including attendance, was analyzed as the dependent variable.\n\n Findings are summarized based on quantitative analysis of the evidence.\n\n\nResults\nThe results show consistent support for a positive relation between more autonomous forms of motivation and exercise, with a trend towards identified regulation predicting initial/short-term adoption more strongly than intrinsic motivation, and intrinsic motivation being more predictive of long-term exercise adherence.\n\n The literature is also consistent in that competence satisfaction and more intrinsic motives positively predict exercise participation across a range of samples and settings.\n\n Mixed evidence was found concerning the role of other types of motives (e.\n\ng.\n\n, health/fitness and body-related), and also the specific nature and consequences of introjected regulation.\n\n The majority of studies have employed descriptive (i.\n\ne.\n\n, non-experimental) designs but similar results are found across cross-sectional, prospective, and experimental designs.\n\n\nConclusion\nOverall, the literature provides good evidence for the value of SDT in understanding exercise behavior, demonstrating the importance of autonomous (identified and intrinsic) regulations in fostering physical activity.\n\n Nevertheless, there remain some inconsistencies and mixed evidence with regard to the relations between specific SDT constructs and exercise.\n\n Particular limitations concerning the different associations explored in the literature are discussed in the context of refining the application of SDT to exercise and physical activity promotion, and integrating these with avenues for future research.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3441783","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Pedro Behaviors and Quality of Life among Chinese Adults","abstract":"Background: The coronavirus disease 2019 (COVID-19) pandemic has created challenges that have caused profound changes in health behaviors.\n This study aimed to explore how COVID-19 is affecting the health-related quality of life (QoL) among Chinese adults.\n Methods: The data of health-related behaviors and QoL were collected via online surveys from 2289 adults (mean age = 27.8 ± 12 years) who had been isolated at home for an average of 77 days.\n Results: More than 50% of the respondents reported that their time engaged in daily physical activity (PA) decreased, while sedentary behavior (SB) time increased compared with that before the lockdown.\n Only 20% of the respondents reported engaging in moderate-to-vigorous PA, 23% of adults reported changed their diets to be healthier, and 30% reported consuming more vegetables, fruits, and milk products than before home-isolation.\n During home-isolation, 75.2% of the adults rated their sleep quality as very good, and 65% reported that they were satisfied with their QoL.\n Sleep quality mediated the relationship between PA and QoL.\n Conclusion: The two-to-three-month home-isolation has had mixed effects on adult health behaviors in China.\n The participants were found to have focused more on their eating quality and patterns, which had a positive influence on their QoL.\n However, people should be encouraged to exercise at home with limited space to maintain a generally healthy lifestyle during a prolonged Participants completed a modified validated questionnaire that assessed the Impact of Event Scale (IES), indicators of negative mental health impacts, social and family support, and mental health-related lifestyle changes.\n A total of 263 participants (106 males and 157 females) completed the study.\n The mean age of the participants was 37.7 ± 14.0 years, and 74.9% had a high level of education.\n The mean IES score in the participants was 13.6 ± 7.7, reflecting a mild stressful impact.\n Only 7.6% of participants had an IES score ?26. The majority of participants (53.3%) did not feel helpless due to the pandemic.\n On the other hand, 52.1% of participants felt horrified and apprehensive due to the pandemic.\n Additionally, the majority of participants (57.877.9%) received increased support from friends and family members, increased shared feeling and caring with family members and others.\n In conclusion, the COVID-19 pandemic was associated with mild stressful impact in our sample, even though the COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing.\n These findings would need to be verified in larger population studies.\n","id":"PMC7177660","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Yingfei","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zheng Feei","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zheng Feei","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"NULL","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Urban Stress Survey Report Shanghai","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/ijerph16162941","date":"2019-08-13","title":"Associations between Self-Determined Motivation, Accelerometer-Determined Physical Activity, and Quality of Life in Chinese College Students","abstract":"Purpose: To better promote college students physical activity (PA) and quality of life (QoL), it is imperative to understand this populations PA correlates, such as self-determined motivation and perceived competence.\n However, few studies existed in this area of inquiry among Chinese college students.\n Thus, the purpose of this study was to examine the relationships among Chinese college students self-determined motivation, PA, and QoL.\n Method: A total of 220 college students (115 females; Mage = 20.29 years, SD = 2.37; MBMI = 20.67) were recruited from one university in south-central China.\n Participants were instructed to wear the ActiGraph GT9X Link (ActiGraph, Pensacola, FL, USA) accelerometers for 7 days.\n A minute-by-minute stepping rate methodology was used to determine participants sedentary behaviors, light physical activity (LPA) and moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA).\n Participants self-determined motivation (autonomous, controlled, and amotivation), perceived competence, and QoL (physical function, stress, depression, fatigue, sleep, and social issues) were assessed by a battery of validated surveys in June 2017. stepping rate revealed participants had average 580.51 min/day in sedentary, 134.77 min/day in LPA, and 1.57 min/day in MVPA.\n Regression analyses for physical function, stress, depression, and social issues suggested that the models explained 4%8% of the variances.\n Specifically, perceived competence was the negative predictor of the problems with physical function (? = ?0.17, p &lt; 0.05) and depression (? = ?0.18, p &lt; 0.01), amotivation was positively associated with depression and stress (p &lt; 0.05).\n Additionally, controlled motivation predicted the ability to participate in social roles and activities (? = 0.22, p &lt; 0.05).\n No significant predictors emerged for fatigue or for sleep.\n Conclusions: Findings suggest Chinese college students perceived competence and social support are critical for improving PA and QoL.\n In addition, strategies are needed to motivate Chinese college students to engage in PA participation and improve overall metabolic syndrome in adults","abstract":"Background\nThe study objectives were to examine whether: 1) sedentary time is associated with sleep duration, 2) sedentary time predicts the metabolic syndrome (MetS) independent of sleep duration and vice versa, and 3) sedentary time and sleep duration have an interactive effect on the MetS.\n\n\nMethods\nThis cross-sectional study is based on the 20032006 National Health and Nutrition Examination Survey.\n\n A sample of 1371 adults (aged ?20 years) were studied.\n\n Average daily sedentary time and sleep duration were determined via 7-day accelerometry.\n\n Screen time was determined via questionnaire.\n\n The MetS was determined using standard criteria.\n\n Analysis of variance was used to examine relationships among sedentary time and screen time with sleep duration.\n\n Logistic regression was used to examine associations between sedentary time, screen time, and sleep duration with the MetS after controlling for several confounders.\n\n\nResults\nSedentary time and screen time did not vary across sleep duration quartiles.\n\n Participants in the highest quartile of sedentary time were more likely to have the MetS than participants in the lowest quartile (odds ratio?=?1.60, 95% CI:1.05-2.45).\n\n The odds of the MetS was higher in participants in the highest screen time tertile as compared to the lowest tertile (odds ratio?=?1.67, 95% confidence interval:1.13-2.48).\n\n Sleep duration was not independently related to the MetS.\n\n There were no significant sedentary time X sleep duration interactions on the of sleep as a contributor to obesity in adolescents: impacts on eating and activity behaviors","abstract":"Background\nSleep is an important contributor to physical and mental health; however, chronic sleep deprivation has become common in adolescents, especially on weekdays.\n\n Adolescents aged 1417 years are recommended to sleep between 8 and 10 h per night to maximize overall health and well-being.\n\n Although sleep needs may vary between individuals, sleep duration recommendations are important for surveillance and help inform policies, interventions, and the population of healthy sleep behaviors.\n\n Long sleepers are very rare among teenagers and sleeping too much is not a problem per se; only insufficient sleep is associated with adverse health outcomes in the pediatric population.\n\n Causes of insufficient sleep are numerous and chronic sleep deprivation poses a serious threat to the academic success, health and safety of adolescents.\n\n This article focuses on the link between insufficient sleep and obesity in adolescents.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThis call to action article argues that sleep should be taken more seriously by the public health community and by our society in general, i.\n\ne.\n\n, given as much attention and resources as nutrition and physical activity.\n\n Not only that having a good nights sleep is as important as eating a healthy diet and being regularly physically active for overall health, but sleeping habits also impact eating and screen time behaviors and, therefore, can influence body weight control.\n\n\nSummary\nShort sleep duration, poor sleep quality, and late bedtimes are all associated with excess food intake, poor diet quality, and obesity in adolescents.\n\n Sleep, sedentary behavior, physical activity and diet all interact and influence each other to ultimately impact health.\n\n A holistic approach to health (i.\n\ne.\n\n, the whole day matters) targeting all of these behaviors synergistically is needed to optimize the impact of our interventions.\n\n Sleep is not a waste of time and sleep hygiene is an important factor to consider in the prevention and treatment of of cardiovascular disease in adults","abstract":"Numerous health behaviors, including physical activity, diet, smoking, and sleep, play a major role in preventing the development and progression of cardiovascular disease (CVD).\n Among these behaviors, sleep may play a pivotal role, yet it has been studied somewhat less than other behaviors and there have been few well-designed sleep intervention studies targeting CVD.\n Furthermore, despite the fact that these behaviors are often interrelated, interventions tend to focus on changing one health behavior rather than concurrently intervening on multiple behaviors.\n Psychological constructs from depression to positive affect may also have a major effect on these health behaviors and ultimately on CVD.\n In this review, we summarize the existing literature on the impact of sleep and other cardiac health behaviors on CVD onset and prognosis.\n We also describe interventions that may promote these behaviors, from established interventions such as motivational interviewing and cognitive behavioral therapy, to more novel approaches focused on mindfulness and other positive psychological constructs.\n Finally, we outline population-health-level care management approaches for patients with psychiatric conditions (e.\ng.\n, depression) that may impact cardiac health, and discuss their potential utility in improving mental health, promoting health behaviors, and reducing CVD-related risk.\n Much work is still needed to better understand how sleep and other health behaviors may uniquely contribute to CVD international physical activity questionnaire short form (IPAQ-SF): A systematic review","abstract":"Background\nThe International Physical Activity Questionnaire - Short Form (IPAQ-SF) has been recommended as a cost-effective method to assess physical activity.\n\n Several studies validating the IPAQ-SF have been conducted with differing results, but no systematic review of these studies has been reported.\n\n\nMethods\nThe keywords 'IPAQ', 'validation', and 'validity' were searched in PubMed and Scopus.\n\n Studies published in English that validated the IPAQ-SF against an objective physical activity measuring device, doubly labeled water, or an objective fitness measure were included.\n\n\nResults\nTwenty-three validation studies were included in this review.\n\n There was a great deal of variability in the methods used across studies, but the results were largely similar.\n\n Correlations between the total physical activity level measured by the IPAQ-SF and objective standards ranged from 0.09 to 0.39; none reached the minimal acceptable standard in the literature (0.50 for objective activity measuring devices, 0.40 for fitness measures).\n\n Correlations between sections of the IPAQ-SF for vigorous activity or moderate activity level/walking and an objective standard showed even greater variability (-0.18 to 0.76), yet several reached the minimal acceptable standard.\n\n Only six studies provided comparisons between physical activity levels derived from the IPAQ-SF and those obtained from objective criterion.\n\n In most studies the IPAQ-SF overestimated physical activity level by 36 to 173 percent; one study underestimated by 28 percent.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe correlation between the IPAQ-SF and objective measures of activity or fitness in the large majority of studies was lower than the acceptable standard.\n\n Furthermore, the IPAQ-SF typically overestimated physical activity as measured by objective criterion by an average of 84 percent.\n\n Hence, the evidence to support the use of the IPAQ-SF as an indicator of relative or absolute physical activity is weak.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3214824","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed popularly used in assessing the subjective quality of life (QOL) of patients and the general public.\n\n We examined its psychometric properties in a large sample of community residents in mainland China.\n\n\nMethods\nThe WHOQOL-BREF was administered to 1052 adult community residents in a major metropolitan city in southern China.\n\n The structural integrity of the 4-factor model in confirmatory factor analyses (CFA) and the relationship of QOL with demographic variables were examined.\n\n Validity was assessed using the known-group comparison (229 with vs.\n\n 823 without chronic illness), item-domain correlations, and CFA using the ML estimation in LISREL.\n\n\nResults\nInternal consistency reliability of the whole instrument (26 items) was 0.89, and the psychological, social, and environment domains had acceptable reliability (alpha = 0.76, 0.72, 0.78 respectively), while that of the physical domain was slightly lower (? = 0.67).\n\n The respective mean scores of these domains were 13.69, 14.11, 12.33 and 14.56. Item-domain correlations were much higher for corresponding domains than for non-corresponding domains, indicating good convergent validity.\n\n CFA provided a marginally acceptable fit to the a priori four-factor model when two matching content item pairs were allowed to be correlated; ?2 (244) = 1836, RMSEA = 0.088, NNFI = 0.898, CFI = 0.909. This factorial structure was shown to be equivalent between the participants with and without chronic illness.\n\n The differences in means between these two groups were significant but small in some domains; effect size = 0.55, 0.15, 0.18 in the physical, psychological, and social relationship domains respectively.\n\n Furthermore, males had significantly higher QOL scores than females in the psychological domain, while individuals with a younger age, higher income, and higher education levels also had significantly higher QOL.\n\n Compared with the international data, the Chinese in this study had relatively low QOL scores with about 5% of males and 16% of females being at risk for poor QOL.\n\n\nConclusions\nThis study has provided psychometric properties of the WHOQOL-BREF as used indoors (95% confidence interval (CI): 1.348.28) and 3.49 times higher odds of delaying exercise (95%CI: 1.697.21) compared with those mentioning heat as the predominant adverse condition.\n\n cold.\n\n\nConclusion\nThis study found that race, age, and education exacerbate the negative effects of adverse weather conditions on the decision to exercise outdoors.\n\n Accordingly, any psychological impact of quarantine and how to reduce it: rapid review of the evidence","abstract":"The December, 2019 coronavirus disease outbreak has seen many countries ask people who have potentially come into contact with the infection to isolate themselves at home or in a dedicated quarantine facility.\n Decisions on how to apply quarantine should be based on the best available evidence.\n We did a Review of the psychological impact of quarantine using three electronic databases.\n Of 3166 papers found, 24 are included in this Review.\n Most reviewed studies reported negative psychological effects including post-traumatic stress symptoms, confusion, and anger.\n Stressors included longer quarantine duration, infection fears, frustration, boredom, inadequate supplies, inadequate information, financial loss, and stigma.\n Some researchers have suggested long-lasting effects.\n In situations where quarantine is deemed necessary, officials should quarantine individuals for no longer than required, provide clear rationale for quarantine and information about protocols, and ensure sufficient supplies are provided.\n Appeals to altruism by reminding the public about the benefits of quarantine to wider society can be favourable.\n","id":"PMC7158942","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Elsevier Ltd.","authors":[{"firstname":"Samantha there is a need to gather evidence on the\nrole of nutrition in depression, to help develop recommendations and guide future\npsychiatric health care.\n The aim of this systematic review was to synthesize the\nlink between diet quality, measured using a range of predefined indices, and\ndepressive outcomes.\n Medline, Embase and PsychInfo were searched up to\n31st May 2018 for studies that examined adherence to a\nhealthy diet in relation to depressive symptoms or clinical depression.\n Where\npossible, estimates were pooled using random effect meta-analysis with\nstratification by observational study design and dietary score.\n A total of 20\nlongitudinal and 21 cross-sectional studies were included.\n These studies utilized an\narray of dietary measures, including: different measures of adherence to the\nMediterranean diet, the Healthy Eating Index (HEI) and Alternative HEI (AHEI), the\nDietary Approaches to Stop Hypertension, and the Dietary Inflammatory Index.\n The\nmost compelling evidence was found for the Mediterranean diet and incident\ndepression, with a combined relative risk estimate of highest vs.\n lowest adherence\ncategory from four longitudinal studies of 0.67 (95% CI 0.550.82).\n A lower Dietary\nInflammatory Index was also associated with lower depression incidence in four\nlongitudinal studies (relative risk 0.76; 95% CI: 0.630.92).\n There were fewer\nlongitudinal studies using other indices, but they and cross-sectional evidence also\nsuggest an inverse association between healthy diet and depression (e.\ng.\n, relative\nrisk 0.65; 95% CI 0.500.84 for HEI/AHEI).\n To conclude, adhering to a healthy diet,\nin particular a traditional Mediterranean diet, or avoiding a pro-inflammatory diet\nappears to confer some protection against depression in observational studies.\n This\nprovides a reasonable evidence base to assess the role of dietary interventions to\nprevent depression.\n This systematic review was registered in the PROSPERO\nInternational Prospective Register of Systematic Reviews under the number\nCRD42017080579.","id":"PMC6755986","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Nature Publishing Group antioxidative polyphenols and significant amounts of ?-3 fatty acids.\n The present study sought to determine the effect of walnuts on mood in healthy volunteers.\n Sixty-four college students were randomly assigned to two treatment sequences in a crossover fashion: walnutplacebo or placebowalnut.\n At baseline mood was assessed using Profiles of Mood States (POMS).\n Data was collected again after eight weeks of intervention.\n After six-weeks of washout, the intervention groups followed the diets in reverse order.\n Data was collected once more at the end of the eight-week intervention period.\n No significant changes in mood were observed in the analyses with both genders combined and in females.\n However, we have observed a significant medium effect size improvement in the Total Mood Disturbance score (?27.49%, p = 0.043, Cohens d = 0.708) in males.\n In non-depressed healthy young males, walnuts seem to have the ability to improve found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjopen-2013-004660","date":"2014-06-16","title":"Effect of tree nuts on metabolic syndrome criteria: a systematic review and meta-analysis of randomised controlled trials","abstract":"Objective\nTo provide a broader evidence summary to inform dietary guidelines of the effect of tree nuts on criteria of the metabolic syndrome (MetS).\n\n\nDesign\nWe conducted a systematic review and meta-analysis of the effect of tree nuts on criteria of the MetS.\n\n\nData sources\nWe searched MEDLINE, EMBASE, CINAHL and the Cochrane Library (through 4 April 2014).\n\n\nEligibility criteria for selecting studies\nWe included relevant randomised controlled trials (RCTs) of ?3?weeks reporting at least one criterion of the MetS.\n\n\nData extraction\nTwo or more independent reviewers extracted all relevant data.\n\n Data were pooled using the generic inverse variance method using random effects models and expressed as mean differences (MD) with 95% CIs.\n\n Heterogeneity was assessed by the Cochran Q statistic and quantified by the I2 statistic.\n\n Study quality and risk of bias were assessed.\n\n\nResults\nEligibility criteria were met by 49 RCTs including 2226 participants who were otherwise healthy or had dyslipidaemia, MetS or type 2 diabetes mellitus.\n\n Tree nut interventions lowered triglycerides (MD=?0.06?mmol/L (95% CI ?0.09 to ?0.03?mmol/L)) and fasting blood glucose (MD=?0.08?mmol/L (95% CI ?0.16 to ?0.01?mmol/L)) compared with control diet interventions.\n\n There was no effect on waist circumference, high-density lipoprotein cholesterol or blood pressure with the direction of effect favouring tree nuts for waist circumference.\n\n There was evidence of significant unexplained heterogeneity in all analyses (p&lt;0.05).\n\n\nConclusions\nPooled analyses show a MetS benefit of tree nuts through modest decreases in triglycerides and fasting blood glucose with no adverse effects on other criteria across nut types.\n\n As our conclusions are limited by the short duration and poor quality of the majority of trials, as well as significant unexplained between-study heterogeneity, there remains a need for larger, longer, high-quality trials.\n\n\nTrial registration number\nNCT01630980.\n","id":"PMC4120343","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BMJ Publishing Group","authors":[{"firstname":"Sonia","surname":"Blanco intervention trials","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3390/nu2070652","date":"2010-06-17","title":"Health Benefits of Nut Consumption","abstract":" Nuts (tree nuts and peanuts) are nutrient dense foods with complex matrices rich in unsaturated fatty and other bioactive compounds: high-quality vegetable protein, fiber, minerals, tocopherols, phytosterols, and phenolic compounds.\n By virtue of their unique composition, nuts are likely to beneficially impact health outcomes.\n Epidemiologic studies have associated nut consumption with a reduced incidence of coronary heart disease and gallstones in both genders and diabetes in women.\n Limited evidence also suggests beneficial effects on hypertension, cancer, and inflammation.\n Interventional studies consistently show that nut intake has a cholesterol-lowering effect, even in the context of healthy diets, and there is emerging evidence of beneficial effects on oxidative stress, inflammation, and vascular reactivity.\n Blood pressure, visceral adiposity and the metabolic syndrome also appear to be positively influenced by nut consumption.\n Thus it is clear that nuts have a beneficial impact on many cardiovascular risk factors.\n Contrary to expectations, epidemiologic studies and clinical trials suggest that regular nut consumption is unlikely to contribute to obesity and may even help in weight loss.\n Safety concerns are limited to the infrequent occurrence of nut allergy in children.\n In conclusion, nuts are nutrient rich foods with wide-ranging cardiovascular and metabolic benefits, which can be readily incorporated into healthy diets.\n","id":"PMC3257681","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Emilio","surname":"Ros","email":"NULL","contributions":"2"}]},{"doi":"10.1007/s11920-009-0082-1","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Neuroinflammation found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1741-7015-11-208","date":"2013-08-02","title":"Mediterranean dietary pattern and depression: the PREDIMED randomized trial","abstract":"Background\nA few observational studies have found an inverse association between adherence to a Mediterranean diet and the risk of depression.\n\n Randomized trials with an intervention based on this dietary pattern could provide the most definitive answer to the findings reported by observational studies.\n\n The aim of this study was to compare in a randomized trial the effects of two Mediterranean diets versus a low-fat diet on depression risk after at least 3 years of intervention.\n\n\nMethods\nThis was a multicenter, randomized, primary prevention field trial of cardiovascular disease (Prevención con Dieta Mediterránea (PREDIMED Study)) based on community-dwelling men aged 55 to 80 years and women aged 60 to 80 years at high risk of cardiovascular disease (51% of them had type 2 diabetes; DM2) attending primary care centers affiliated with 11 Spanish teaching hospitals.\n\n Primary analyses were performed on an intention-to-treat basis.\n\n Cox regression models were used to assess the relationship between the nutritional intervention groups and the incidence of depression.\n\n\nResults\nWe identified 224 new cases of depression during follow-up.\n\n There was an inverse association with depression for participants assigned to a Mediterranean diet supplemented with nuts (multivariate hazard ratio (HR) 0.78; 95% confidence interval (CI) 0.55 to 1.10) compared with participants assigned to the control group, although this was not significant.\n\n However, when the analysis was restricted to participants with DM2, the magnitude of the effect of the intervention with the Mediterranean diet supplemented with nuts did reach statistical significance (multivariate HR = 0.59; 95% CI 0.36 to 0.98).\n\n\nConclusions\nThe result suggest that a Mediterranean diet supplemented with nuts could exert a beneficial effect on the risk of depression in patients with DM2.\nTrial registration\nThis trial has been registered in the Current SFA and MUFA","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1155/2014/313570","date":"2014-02-07","title":"Omega-3 Fatty Acids and Depression: Scientific Evidence and Biological Mechanisms","abstract":"The changing of omega-6/omega-3 polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) in the food supply of Western societies occurred over the last 150 years is thought to promote the pathogenesis of many inflammatory-related diseases, including depressive disorders.\n Several epidemiological studies reported a significant inverse correlation between intake of oily fish and depression or bipolar disorders.\n Studies conducted specifically on the association between omega-3 intake and depression reported contrasting results, suggesting that the preventive role of omega-3 PUFA may depend also on other factors, such as overall diet quality and the social environment.\n Accordingly, tertiary prevention with omega-3 PUFA supplement in depressed patients has reached greater effectiveness during the last recent years, although definitive statements on their use in depression therapy cannot be yet freely asserted.\n Among the biological properties of omega-3 PUFA, their anti-inflammatory effects and their important role on the structural changing of the brain should be taken into account to better understand the possible pathway through which they can be effective both in preventing or treating depression.\n However, the problem of how to correct the inadequate supply of omega-3 PUFA in the Westernized countries' diet is a priority in order to set food and health policies and also dietary recommendations for individuals and population groups.\n","id":"PMC3976923","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Hindawi Publishing Executive summary of a symposium","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1471-2288-2-8","date":"2002-06-17","title":"Do multiple outcome measures require p-value adjustment?","abstract":"Background\nReaders may question the interpretation of findings in clinical trials when multiple outcome measures are used without adjustment of the p-value.\n\n This question arises because of the increased risk of Type I errors (findings of false 'significance') when multiple simultaneous hypotheses are tested at set p-values.\n\n The primary aim of this study was to estimate the need to make appropriate p-value adjustments in clinical trials to compensate for a possible increased risk in committing Type I errors when multiple outcome measures are used.\n\n\nDiscussion\nThe classicists believe that the chance of finding at least one test statistically significant due to chance and incorrectly declaring a difference increases as the number of comparisons increases.\n\n The rationalists have the following objections to that theory: 1) P-value adjustments are calculated based on how many tests are to be considered, and that number has been defined arbitrarily and variably; 2) P-value adjustments reduce the chance of making type I errors, but they increase the chance of making type II errors or needing to increase the sample size.\n\n\nSummary\nReaders should balance a study's statistical significance with the magnitude of effect, the quality of the study and with findings from other studies.\n\n Researchers facing multiple outcome measures might want to either select a primary outcome measure or use a global assessment measure, rather than adjusting the p-value.\n\n\n","id":"PMC117123","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed Central","authors":[{"firstname":"Ronald Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[],"References depth 2":[]},{"doi":"10.1038/s41366-018-0299-3","date":"1970-01-01","title":"The Influence of 15-week Exercise Training on Dietary Patterns among Young Adults","abstract":"BACKGROUND/OBJECTIVES:\nid='P1'>Little is currently known about how exercise may influence dietary patterns and/or food preferences.\n\n The present study aimed to examine the effect of a 15-week exercise training program on overall dietary patterns among young adults.\n\n\nSUBJECTS/METHODS:\nid='P2'>This study consisted of 2680 young adults drawn from the Training Intervention and Genetics of Exercise Response (TIGER) study.\n\n Subjects underwent 15 weeks of aerobic exercise training, and exercise duration, intensity, and dose were recorded for each session using computerized heart rate monitors.\n\n In total, 4355 dietary observations with 102 food items were collected using a self-administered food frequency questionnaire before and after exercise training (n = 2476 at baseline; n = 1859 at 15 weeks).\n\n Dietary patterns were identified using a Bayesian sparse latent factor model.\n\n Changes in dietary pattern preferences were evaluated based on the pre/post-training differences in dietary pattern scores, accounting for the effects of gender, race/ethnicity, and BMI.\n\n\nRESULTS:\nid='P3'>Within each of the seven dietary patterns identified, most dietary pattern scores were decreased following exercise training, consistent with increased voluntary regulation of food intake.\n\n A longer duration of exercise was associated with decreased preferences for the Western (?: ?0.0793; 95% credible interval: ?0.1568, ?0.0017) and Snacking (?: ?0.1280; 95% credible interval: ?0.1877, ?0.0637) patterns, while a higher intensity of exercise was linked to an increased preference for the Prudent pattern (?: 0.0623; 95% credible interval: 0.0159, 0.1111).\n\n Consequently, a higher dose of exercise was related to a decreased preference for the Snacking pattern (?: ?0.0023; 95% credible interval: ?0.0042, ?0.0004) and an increased preference for the Prudent pattern (?: 0.0029; 95% credible interval: 0.0009, 0.0048).\n\n\nCONCLUSION:\nid='P4'>The 15-week exercise training appeared to motivate young adults to pursue healthier dietary preferences and to regulate their food intake.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6639161","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Oxford University Students: A Pilot Study","abstract":"Background\nIn transitioning from adolescence to adulthood, college students are faced with significant challenges to their health habits.\n\n Independence, stress, and perceived lack of time by college students have been known to result in poor eating and exercise habits, which can lead to increased disease risk.\n\n\nObjective\nTo assess the feasibility delivered via email to 148 college students.\n\n The intervention involved weekly, tailored, and interactive diet and physical activity goals.\n\n The control group received nondiet and nonexercise-related health fact sheets.\n\n Anthropometric and blood pressure measurements, as well as food frequency and physical activity surveys were conducted at baseline, week 12, and week 24. Students choice of fruit as a snack was also monitored at study visits.\n\n\nResults\nStudents were 18-20 years old, 69% female, and from a diverse college campus (46% Caucasian, 23% Asian, 20% African American, 11% other).\n\n At week 24, 84% of students reported reading at least half of all emails.\n\n Mean change (standard error [SE]) from baseline of saturated fat intake was marginally significant between the treatment groups at week 24, 0.7 (SE 0.42) % kcal for control and -0.3 (SE 0.30) % kcal for intervention (P=0.048).\n\n A significant difference in percent of snacks chosen that were fruit (?2\n1, N=221 = 11.7, P&lt;0.001) was detected between the intervention and control group at week 24.\nConclusions\nUse of an electronic wellness program is feasible in college a principal factor analysis has been performed to identify sample subgroups.\n An increased energy intake (+17.8% at T3; p &lt; 0.01) has been observed, although macronutrients proportions did not vary over time, without differences between sexes.\n An increase of free fat mass was found in the last mesocycle (+3.8%), without an augmentation of body weight, when, despite the increased training load, a stabilization of energy intake occurred.\n Three different subgroups characterized by different dietary modifications could be identified among participants that showed a common trend towards a healthier diet.\n Nine weeks of HIIT promoted a spontaneous modulation of food choices and regulation of dietary intake in young normal-weight subjects aged 2124. Importantly, this life-period is critical to lay the foundation of correct lifestyles to prevent metabolic diseases and secure a healthy future with advancing Snack Choice: Healthy Snack Choice is Reduced in the Post-Exercise State","abstract":"Acute exercise can induce either a compensatory increase in food intake or a reduction in food intake, which results from appetite suppression in the post-exercise state.\n The timing of food choicechoosing for immediate or later consumptionhas been found to influence the healthfulness of foods consumed.\n To examine both of these effects, we tested in our study whether the timing of food choice interacts with exposure to exercise to impact food choices such that choices would differ when made prior to or following an exercise bout.\n Visitors to a university recreational center were equipped with an accelerometer prior to their habitual workout regime, masking the true study purpose.\n As a reward, participants were presented with a snack for consumption after workout completion.\n Participants made their snack choice from either an apple or chocolate brownie after being pseudo-randomly assigned to choose prior to (before) or following workout completion (after).\n Complete data were available for 256 participants (54.7% male, 22.1 ± 3.1 years, 24.7 ± 3.7 kg/m2) who exercised 65.3 ± 22.5 min/session.\n When compared with before, the choice of an apple decreased (73.7% vs.\n 54.6%) and the choices of brownie (13.9% vs.\n 20.2%) or no snack (12.4% vs.\n 25.2%) increased in the after condition (?2 = 26.578, p &lt; 0.001).\n Our results provide support for both compensatory eating and exercise-induced anorexia.\n More importantly, our findings suggest that the choice of food for post-exercise consumption can be altered through a simple behavioral intervention.\n","id":"PMC6315457","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Christopher and/or food preferences.\n\n The present study aimed to examine the effect of a 15-week exercise training program on overall dietary patterns among young adults.\n\n\nSUBJECTS/METHODS:\nid='P2'>This study consisted of 2680 young adults drawn from the Training Intervention and Genetics of Exercise Response (TIGER) study.\n\n Subjects underwent 15 weeks of aerobic exercise training, and exercise duration, intensity, and dose were recorded for each session using computerized heart rate monitors.\n\n In total, 4355 dietary observations with 102 food items were collected using a self-administered food frequency questionnaire before and after exercise training (n = 2476 at baseline; n = 1859 at 15 weeks).\n\n Dietary patterns were identified using a Bayesian sparse latent factor model.\n\n Changes in dietary pattern preferences were evaluated based on the pre/post-training differences in dietary pattern scores, accounting for the effects of gender, race/ethnicity, and BMI.\n\n\nRESULTS:\nid='P3'>Within each of the seven dietary patterns identified, most dietary pattern scores were decreased following exercise training, consistent with increased voluntary regulation of food intake.\n\n A longer duration of exercise was associated with decreased preferences for the Western (?: ?0.0793; 95% credible interval: ?0.1568, ?0.0017) and Snacking (?: ?0.1280; 95% credible interval: ?0.1877, ?0.0637) patterns, while a higher intensity of exercise was linked to an increased preference for the Prudent pattern (?: 0.0623; 95% credible interval: 0.0159, 0.1111).\n\n Consequently, a higher dose of exercise was related to a decreased preference for the Snacking pattern (?: ?0.0023; 95% credible interval: ?0.0042, ?0.0004) and an increased preference for the Prudent pattern (?: 0.0029; 95% credible interval: 0.0009, 0.0048).\n\n\nCONCLUSION:\nid='P4'>The 15-week exercise training appeared to motivate young adults to pursue healthier dietary preferences and to short-HIIT (n=10).\n The long-HIIT group performed fifteen 1-min bouts at 90% of maximum heart rate (HRmax), interspersed by 30-sec active recovery (60% HRmax).\n The short-HIIT group performed forty-five 20-sec bouts at 90% of HRmax, interspersed by 10-sec active recovery (60% HRmax).\n The training for both groups was conducted 3 times a week for 6 weeks.\n All subjects performed the acid-alanine-carbohydrate-based sports supplement on perceived exertion and performance in high intensity endurance cycling tests","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>Sports nutritional supplements containing branched-chain amino acids (BCAA) have been widely reported to improve psychological and biological aspects connected to central fatigue and performance in endurance exercise, although the topic is still open to debate.\n\n The aim of the present study was to determine whether the intake of a commercially available BCAA-based supplement, taken according to the manufacturers recommendations, could affect the rating of perceived exertion (RPE) and performance indexes at the beginning (1d) and end of a 9-week (9w) scheduled high intensity interval training program, with an experimental approach integrating the determination of psychometric, performance, metabolic and blood biochemical parameters.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>This was a randomized double-blind placebo-controlled study.\n\n Thirty-two untrained, healthy young adults (20 males and 12 female) were enrolled.\n\n A high-intensity endurance cycling (HIEC) test was used to induce fatigue in the participants: HIEC consisted in ten 90?s sprints interspersed by ten 3?min recovery phases and followed by a final step time to exhaustion was used.\n\n In parallel with RPE, haematological values (creatine kinase, alanine, BCAA, tryptophan, ammonia and glucose levels), and performance indexes (maximal oxygen consumption - VO2max, power associated with lactate thresholds - WLT1, WLT2 and time to exhaustion - TTE) were assessed.\n\n All subject took the supplement (13.2?g of carbohydrates; 3.2?g of BCAA and 1.6?g of L-alanine per dose) or placebo before each test and training session.\n\n Dietary habits and training load were monitored during the entire training period.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The administration of the supplement (SU) at 1d reduced RPE by 9% during the recovery phase, as compared to the placebo (PL); at 9w the RPE scores were reduced by 13 and 21% during the sprint and recovery phase, respectively; at 9w, prolonged supplement intake also improved TTE and TRIMP.\n\n SU intake invariably promoted a rapid increase (within 1?h) of BCAA serum blood levels and prevented the post-HIEC tryptophan: BCAA ratio increase found in the PL group, at both 1d and 9w.\n\n There was no difference in dietary habits between groups and those habits did not change over time; no difference in glycemia was found between SU and PL.\n\n VO2max, WLT1 and WLT2 values improved over time, but were unaffected by supplement intake.\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>On the whole, these results suggest that i) the intake of the BCAA-based commercially available supplement used in this study reduces RPE as a likely consequence of an improvement in the serum tryptophan: BCAA ratio; ii) over time, reduced RPE allows subjects to sustain higher workloads, leading to increased TRIMP and TTE.\n\n\n","id":"PMC6971972","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed continuous moderate intensity training (MIT) for improving body composition, insulin sensitivity (SI), blood pressure, blood lipids, and cardiovascular fitness in a cohort of sedentary overweight or obese young men.\n\n We hypothesized that HIIT would result in similar improvements in body composition, cardiovascular fitness, blood lipids, and SI as compared to the MIT group, despite requiring only one hour of activity per week compared to five hours per week for the MIT group.\n\n\nMethods\n28 sedentary overweight or obese men (age, 20 ± 1.5 years, body mass index 29.5 ± 3.3 kg/m2) treadmill exercise test to measure cardiovascular fitness, oral glucose tolerance to measure SI, nuclear magnetic resonance spectroscopy to assess lipoprotein particles, and automatic auscultation to measure blood pressure.\n\n\nResults\nA greater improvement in VO2peak was observed in MIT compared to HIIT (11.1% vs 2.83%, P = 0.0185) in the complete-case analysis.\n\n No differences were seen in the intention to treat analysis, and no other group differences were observed.\n\n Both exercise conditions were associated with temporal improvements in % body fat, total cholesterol, medium VLDL, medium HDL, triglycerides, SI, and VO2peak (P &lt; 0.05).\n\n\nConclusion\nParticipation in HIIT or MIT exercise training displayed: 1) improved SI, 2) reduced blood lipids, 3) decreased % body fat, and 4) improved cardiovascular fitness.\n\n While both exercise groups led to similar improvements for most cardiometabolic risk factors assessed, MIT led to a greater improvement in overall cardiovascular fitness.\n\n Overall, these observations suggest that a relatively short duration of either HIIT or MIT training may improve cardiometabolic risk factors in previously sedentary oxygen consumption (EPOC) during exercise of the spending the same calories between the continuous and interval exercise.\n\n\n[Methods]\nThirty-four healthy college students who did not regularly exercise volunteered to participate in our study.\n\n Continuous exercise was performed on an ergometer for 30 min at 60% of maximal oxygen consumption (VO2 max).\n\n Interval exercise was performed on a cycle ergometer at 80% VO2 max for 2 min initially, followed by 40% VO2 max for 1 min, and 80% VO2 max for 3 min.\n\n This was repeated six times for a total of 26 min.\n\n\n[Results]\nThe major findings were as follows: (1) energy consumption during exercise was not significantly different between continuous exercise and interval exercise groups; (2) EPOC was higher in interval exercise than in continuous exercise for all dependent variables (i.\n\ne.\n\n, total oxygen consumption, total calories, summation of heart rate); and (3) there were no significant differences in the lipid profile between continuous and interval groups.\n\n\n[Conclusion]\nOur study confirmed that after equalizing energy expenditure for continuous and interval exercise on a cycle ergometer in subjects in their found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0029840","date":"2011-12-06","title":"The 24-h Energy Intake of Obese Adolescents Is Spontaneously Reduced after Intensive Exercise: A Randomized Controlled Trial in Calorimetric Chambers","abstract":"Background\nPhysical exercise can modify subsequent energy intake and appetite and may thus be of particular interest in terms of obesity treatment.\n\n However, it is still unclear whether an intensive bout of exercise can affect the energy consumption of obese children and adolescents.\n\n\nObjective\nTo compare the impact of high vs.\n\n moderate intensity exercises on subsequent 24-h energy intake, macronutrient preferences, appetite sensations, energy expenditure and balance in obese adolescent.\n\n\nDesign\nThis randomized cross-over trial involves 15 obese adolescent boys who were asked to randomly complete three 24-h sessions in a metabolic chamber, each separated by at least 7 days: (1) sedentary (SED); (2) Low-Intensity Exercise (LIE) (40% maximal oxygen uptake, VO2max); (3) High-Intensity Exercise (HIE) (75%VO2max).\n\n\nResults\nDespite unchanged appetite sensations, 24-h total energy intake following HIE was 611% lower compared to LIE and SED (p&lt;0.05), whereas no differences appeared between SED and LIE.\n\n Energy intake at lunch was 9.4% and 8.4% lower after HIE compared to SED and LIE, respectively (p&lt;0.05).\n\n At dinner time, it was 20.5% and 19.7% lower after HIE compared to SED and LIE, respectively (p&lt;0.01).\n\n 24-h energy expenditure was not significantly altered.\n\n Thus, the 24-h energy balance was significantly reduced during HIE compared to SED and LIE (p&lt;0.01), whereas those of SED and LIE did not differ.\n\n\nConclusions\nIn obese adolescent boys, HIE has a beneficial impact on 24-h energy balance, mainly due to the spontaneous decrease in energy intake during lunch and dinner following the exercise bout.\n\n Prescribing high-intensity exercises to promote weight loss may therefore provide effective results without affecting appetite sensations and, as a result, food frustrations.\n\n\nTrial Registration\nClinicalTrial.\n\ngov NCT01036360\n\n","id":"PMC3260158","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of considered a time-efficient exercise strategy for weight management.\n However, data regarding the acute appetite and energy intake responses to HIIT versus continuous training remain inconclusive.\n This study investigated the ad libitum energy intake and appetite responses to a single session of HIIT versus moderate-intensity continuous training (MICT) and vigorous-intensity continuous training (VICT).\n Using a randomized crossover design, 11 middle-aged physically inactive men (45.7 ± 7.4 years, 23.5 ± 2.1 kg m?2) participated in three treadmill trials at 7-day intervals.\n HIIT comprised 10 1-min periods at 100% VO2max interspersed with 1-min periods of active recovery.\n MICT comprised a 40-min session at 65% VO2max, while VICT comprised a 20-min session at 80% VO2max.\n After each trial, the participants consumed an ad libitum buffet meal for which the energy intake was recorded.\n The participants perceived appetite was assessed before and after exercise sessions using the Visual Analogue Scale (VAS).\n No significant differences in post-exercise ad libitum energy intake were observed between trials (HIIT: 645 ± 262.9 kcal; MICT: 614.7 ± 271.2 kcal; VICT: 623.1 ± 249.0 kcal, p &gt; 0.05).\n Although the perceived appetite responses exhibited a significant main effect of time (p &lt; 0.01), no group differences were observed (p &gt; 0.05).\n In summary, these findings suggest that the interval or continuous nature of exercise has no significant effect on appetite responses in physically inactive middle-aged adults, at least during the short-term post-exercise period.\n","id":"PMC6213307","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Eric
