found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/mhealth.2827","date":"2014-03-13","title":"Usage of Social Media and Smartphone Application in Assessment of Physical and Psychological Well-Being of Individuals in Times of a Major Air Pollution Crisis","abstract":"Background\nCrisis situations bring about many challenges to researchers, public institutions, and governments in collecting data and conducting research in affected individuals.\n\n Recent developments in Web-based and smartphone technologies have offered government and nongovernment organizations a new system to disseminate and acquire information.\n\n However, research into this area is still lacking.\n\n The current study focuses largely on how new social networking websites and, in particular, smartphone technologies could have helped in the acquisition of crucial research data from the general population during the recent 2013 Southeast Asian Haze.\n\n This crisis lasted only for 1 week, and is unlike other crisis where there are large-scale consequential after-effects.\n\n\nObjective\nTo determine whether respondents will make use of Internet, social media, and smartphone technologies to provide feedback regarding their physical and psychological wellbeing during a crisis, and if so, will these new mechanisms be as effective as conventional, technological, Internet-based website technologies.\n\n\nMethods\nA Web-based database and a smartphone application were developed.\n\n Participants were recruited by snowball sampling.\n\n The participants were recruited either via a self-sponsored Facebook post featuring a direct link to the questionnaire on physical and psychological wellbeing and also a smartphone Web-based application; or via dissemination of the questionnaire link by emails, directed to the same group of participants.\n\n Information pertaining to physical and psychological wellbeing was collated.\n\n\nResults\nA total of 298 respondents took part in the survey.\n\n Most of them were between the ages of 20 to 29 years and had a university education.\n\n More individuals preferred the option of accessing and providing feedback to a survey on physical and psychological wellbeing via direct access to a Web-based questionnaire.\n\n Statistical analysis showed that demographic variables like age, gender, and educational levels did not influence the mechanism of access.\n\n\nIn addition, the participants reported a mean number of 4.03 physical symptoms (SD 2.6).\n\n The total Impact of Event ScaleRevised (IES-R) score was 18.47 (SD 11.69), which indicated that the study population did experience psychological stress but not post-traumatic stress disorder.\n\n The perceived dangerous Pollutant Standards Index (PSI) level and the number of physical symptoms were associated with higher IES-R Score (P&lt;.\n\n05).\n\n\nConclusions\nThis is one of the first few studies demonstrating the use of Internet in data collection during an air-pollution crisis.\n\n Our results demonstrated that the newer technological modalities have the potential to acquire data, similar to that of conventional technologies.\n\n Demographic variables did not influence the mechanism of usage.\n\n In addition, our findings also suggested that there are acute physical and psychological impacts on the population from an air-pollution crisis.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4114481","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"JMIR Publications agonist maintenance treatment (MMT) is used to treat opioid addiction by preventing opioid withdrawal and reducing cravings.\n\n However, it is important to note that mental conditions may persist, or even remain undetected while methadone maintenance treatment is ongoing.\n\n This study aimed to examine the level of psychological problems among MMT patients at public and private health facilities and identify associated factors.\n\n\nMethod\nid='Par2'>From January to September 2018, a cross-sectional study was performed in Nam Dinh province, one of the largest epicenters providing HIV/AIDS surveillance and treatment services in the North of Vietnam.\n\n 395 male respondents currently receiving MMT agreed to participate in a face-to-face interview.\n\n Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale-21 (DASS-21) were used to assess psychological problems among patients.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>The percentage of patients suffering from mild to extremely severe anxiety was the highest among psychological problems (18%).\n\n 2.8% of participants had mild depressive symptoms and the percentage of those having mild or moderate stress was approximately 4%.\n\n In addition, the longer treatment duration, the lower mental health scores regarding three types of psychological problems.\n\n Respondents who received MMT services in public health facilities were more likely to have a higher score of all psychological problems.\n\n Participants who lived with partners or spouse, having higher monthly family income had a lower likelihood of having severe depression and stress status.\n\n Freelancers or blue-collars/farmers had lower score of depression and anxiety compared to people being unemployed.\n\n\nConclusion\nid='Par4'>This study suggests that among our sample, MMT patients receiving treatment in public health facilities might have higher rate of psychological problems, including depression, anxiety, and stress than that of those in the private health facility.\n\n These results highlight the necessity of taking psychological counseling adequately for MMT patients and psychological assessment should be prioritized in the early stage of Comparison between Depressed and Non-Depressed Smokers in Singapore","abstract":"The rising prevalence of smokers in the community, specifically psychiatric patients, necessitates smoking cessation as an important strategy for reducing the harmful effects of tobacco.\n This study aims to compare the profiles of depressed and non-depressed smokers and evaluate how psychiatric symptoms influence respiratory symptoms.\n A cross-sectional survey was administered to 276 non-depressed adult smokers in the community and 69 adult smokers who had been formally diagnosed with depression in the outpatient clinic of a University Hospital in Singapore.\n Participants were administered questionnaires on smoking attitudes and perceptions, psychiatric symptoms, and respiratory symptoms.\n Correlations and multiple regression analyses were conducted.\n The mean age of smokers in the study was 35.32 ± 13.05 years.\n Smokers in the community and psychiatric samples were largely similar on all of the sociodemographic factors, except that fewer depressed people were employed (?2 = 8.35, p &lt; 0.01).\n Smokers with depression also reported more attempts to quit smoking (?2 = 7.14, p &lt; 0.05), higher mean depressive, anxiety, and stress symptom (DASS) scores (t = ?10.04, p &lt; 0.01), and endorsed more respiratory symptoms than smokers in the community (t = ?2.40, p &lt; 0.05).\n The DASS scores, number of cigarettes smoked daily, years of smoking, general perception of smokers getting heart disease, and presence of lung disease were positively and significantly correlated with respiratory symptoms.\n On multiple regression, only anxiety symptoms (? = 0.26, p &lt; 0.05) and the presence of lung disease (? = 0.22, p &lt; 0.001) were significantly correlated with respiratory symptoms.\n Depressed smokers reported greater difficulty in quitting tobacco use, and they perceived more severe respiratory symptoms compared to non-depressed counterparts.\n Anxiety symptoms were positively associated with the severity of respiratory symptoms.\n Smoking cessation campaigns need to specifically target psychological symptoms in smokers and focus more psychoeducation on the risk Study","abstract":"Misophonia, also known as selective sound sensitivity syndrome, is a condition characterized by strong dislike of specific sounds with accompanying distressing reactions.\n To date, misophonia is still poorly understood.\n This study aimed to identify factors associated with severity of misophonic symptoms in Singaporean psychiatric patients.\n Ninety-two psychiatric patients were recruited from a large teaching hospital in Singapore in a cross-sectional study.\n Socio-demographics, severity of depression, anxiety and stress, and severity of misophonic symptoms were analyzed.\n Correlation analysis showed that anxiety, depression, and stress scoresas measured by the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scales-21 (DASS-21)were significantly positively correlated with the Amsterdam Misophonia Scale (A-MISO-S) scores.\n After adjustment for confounding factors, multivariate regression analysis showed that anxiety (? = 0.385, p = 0.029) remained significantly associated with A-MISO-S.\n Age, gender, depression, and stress were not significantly associated with the severity of misophonia.\n The findings showed that the severity of anxiety was associated with severity of misophonia in Singaporean psychiatric patients.\n Further research is needed to explore the nature of misophonia and its relationship with other psychiatric of Depression in the Community from 30 Countries between 1994 and 2014","abstract":"id='Par1'>The prevalence of depression may be affected by changes in psychiatric practices and the availability of online mental health information in the past two decades.\n This study aimed to evaluate the aggregate prevalence of depression in communities from different countries between 1994 and 2014 and to explore the variations in prevalence stratified by geographical, methodological and socio-economic factors.\n A total of 90 studies were identified and met the inclusion criteria (n?=?1,112,573 adults) with 68 studies on single point prevalence, 9 studies on one-year prevalence, and 13 studies on lifetime prevalence of depression.\n A random-effects model meta-analysis that was performed to calculate the aggregate point, one-year and lifetime prevalence of depression calculated prevalences of 12.9%, 7.2% and 10.8% respectively.\n Point prevalence of depression was significantly higher in women (14.4%), countries with a medium human development index (HDI) (29.2%), studies published from 2004 to 2014 (15.4%) and when using self-reporting instruments (17.3%) to assess depression.\n Heterogeneity was identified by meta-regression and subgroup analysis, and response rate, percentage of women and year of publication, respectively, were determined contribute to depression prevalence.\n This meta-analysis allows benchmarking of the prevalence of depression during the era when online health information emerged, facilitating future comparisons.\n","id":"PMC5809481","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Nature Publishing Group UK","authors":[{"firstname":"Grace applications among Vietnamese youth and young adults","abstract":"Background\nid='Par1'>As smartphone becomes increasingly prevalent and affordable, more youths today can own a smartphone device and download applications in various application stores.\n\n Smartphone applications have been proven to be useful for youths in various aspects.\n\n However, there has been a paucity of data looking into the preferences of Vietnamese youths and adolescents with regards to health-related applications and their receptiveness towards smartphone apps.\n\n Therefore, this study aimed to determine the receptiveness and preferences of health-related smartphone applications (mHealth apps) among online Vietnamese youths and adolescents.\n\n\nMethods\nid='Par2'>An online cross-sectional study was conducted between the periods of August till October 2015 in Vietnam.\n\n Respondent-driven sampling technique (RDS) was utilized to recruit participants.\n\n Participants were asked questions about their history of downloading and using health-related smartphone applications and their receptiveness when using these applications.\n\n Moreover, socio-demographic characteristics and health status were also self-reported.\n\n Multivariate logistic regression was employed to determine associated factors.\n\n\nResults\nid='Par3'>Among 1028 participants, 57.4% owned a smartphone and only 14.1% of smartphone users have used a health-related smartphone application, and most of these individuals downloaded the applications for disease prevention (66.3%).\n\n 66.4% of the participants who owned these applications reported that health applications were useful and 92.8% reported being satisfied with the functionalities of the applications which they owned.\n\n Among smartphone users, people who were employed (OR?=?15.46; 95%CI?=?4.9348.47) were more likely to download mHealth apps.\n\n Meanwhile, youths with higher EQ-5D index had a lower likelihood of downloading healthcare-related smartphone applications (OR?=?0.17; 95%CI?=?0.040.81).\n\n\nConclusions\nid='Par4'>This study highlighted a low rate of mHealth apps utilization among online Vietnamese youths and adolescents but a high acceptance of individuals who already used these apps.\n\n Developing mHealth apps or interventions towards the disease prevention and quality of life improvement could be feasible to proliferate the benefits of such applications in youths and adolescents in Vietnam.\n\n Further research should be conducted to optimize the contents and interfaces of mHealth apps that meet the needs of these Participants were recruited by an online recruitment post and snowball sampling techniques.\n\n Participants were required to complete an online survey which was composed of demographics questionnaire, physical symptom checklist, perceived dangerous Pollutant Standard Index (PSI) value and views on the N-95 mask and the Impact of Event Scale-Revised (IES-R).\n\n\nResults\nA total of 298 participants returned the completed study questionnaire.\n\n The respondents reported a mean number of 4.03 physical symptoms (S.\n\nD.\n\n = 2.6).\n\n The five most common physical symptoms include mouth or throat discomfort (68.8%), nose discomfort (64.1%), eye discomfort (60.7%), headache (50.3%) and breathing difficulty (40.3%).\n\n The total IES-R score was 18.47 (S.\n\nD.\n\n = 11.69) which indicated that the study population experienced mild psychological stress but not to the extent of acute stress reaction syndrome.\n\n The perceived dangerous PSI level and number of physical symptoms were significantly associated with the mean intrusion score, mean hyper-arousal score, total mean IES-R score and total IES-R score (p &lt; 0.05).\n\n\nConclusions\nOur findings suggest that a haze crisis is associated with acute physical symptoms and mild psychological stress.\n\n The number of physical symptoms and the perceived dangerous PSI values are important factors recommendations","abstract":"The Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) epidemic emerged in Wuhan, China, spread nationwide and then onto half a dozen other countries between December 2019 and early 2020. The implementation of unprecedented strict quarantine measures in China has kept a large number of people in isolation and affected many aspects of peoples lives.\n It has also triggered a wide variety of psychological problems, such as panic disorder, anxiety and depression.\n This study is the first nationwide large-scale survey of psychological distress in the general population of China during the COVID-19 epidemic.\n","id":"PMC7061893","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BMJ Publishing Group","authors":[{"firstname":"Jianyin","surname":"Qiu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bin","surname":"Shen","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Min","surname":"Zhao","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zhen","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zhen","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Bin","surname":"Xie","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yifeng","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/ijerph17051729","date":"2020-03-03","title":"Immediate Psychological Responses and Associated Factors during the Initial Stage of the 2019 Coronavirus Disease (COVID-19) Epidemic among the General Population in China","abstract":"Background: The 2019 coronavirus disease (COVID-19) epidemic is a public health emergency of international concern and poses a challenge to psychological resilience.\n Research data are needed to develop evidence-driven strategies to reduce adverse psychological impacts and psychiatric symptoms during the epidemic.\n The aim of this study was to survey the general public in China to better understand their levels of psychological impact, anxiety, depression, and stress during the initial stage of the COVID-19 outbreak.\n The data will be used for future reference.\n Methods: From 31 January to 2 February 2020, we conducted an online survey using snowball sampling techniques.\n The online survey collected information on demographic data, physical symptoms in the past 14 days, contact history with COVID-19, knowledge and concerns about COVID-19, precautionary measures against COVID-19, and additional information required with respect to COVID-19. Psychological impact was assessed by the Impact of Event Scale-Revised (IES-R), and mental health status was assessed by the Depression, Anxiety and Stress Scale (DASS-21).\n Results: This study included 1210 respondents from 194 cities in China.\n In total, 53.8% of respondents rated the psychological impact of the outbreak as moderate or severe; 16.5% reported moderate to severe depressive symptoms; 28.8% reported moderate to severe anxiety symptoms; and 8.1% reported moderate to severe stress levels.\n Most respondents spent 2024 h per day at home (84.7%); were worried about their family members contracting COVID-19 (75.2%); and were satisfied with the amount of health information available (75.1%).\n Female gender, student status, specific physical symptoms (e.\ng.\n, myalgia, dizziness, coryza), and poor self-rated health status were significantly associated with a greater psychological impact of the outbreak and higher levels of stress, anxiety, and depression (p &lt; 0.05).\n Specific up-to-date and accurate health information (e.\ng.\n, treatment, local outbreak situation) and particular precautionary measures (e.\ng.\n, hand hygiene, wearing a mask) were associated with a lower psychological impact of the outbreak and lower levels of stress, anxiety, and depression (p &lt; 0.05).\n Conclusions: During the initial phase of the COVID-19 outbreak in China, more than half of the respondents rated the psychological impact as moderate-to-severe, and about one-third reported moderate-to-severe anxiety.\n Our findings identify factors associated with a lower level of psychological impact and better mental health status that can be used to formulate psychological interventions to improve the mental health of vulnerable groups during the COVID-19 epidemic.\n","id":"PMC7084952","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Cuiyan","surname":"Wang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Riyu","surname":"Pan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Riyu","surname":"Pan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiaoyang","surname":"Wan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yilin","surname":"Tan","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Linkang","surname":"Xu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cyrus K.","surname":"Sharma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Cyrus","surname":"Ho","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.3390/ijerph17072381","date":"2020-03-28","title":"Impact of the COVID-19 Pandemic on Mental Health and Quality of Life among Local Residents in Liaoning Province, China: A Cross-Sectional Study","abstract":"Our study aimed to investigate the immediate impact of the COVID-19 pandemic on mental health and quality of life among local Chinese residents aged ?18 years in Liaoning Province, mainland China.\n An online survey was distributed through a social media platform between January and February 2020. Participants completed a modified validated questionnaire that assessed the Impact of Event Scale (IES), indicators of negative mental health impacts, social and family support, and mental health-related lifestyle changes.\n A total of 263 participants (106 males and 157 females) completed the study.\n The mean age of the participants was 37.7 ± 14.0 years, and 74.9% had a high level of education.\n The mean IES score in the participants was 13.6 ± 7.7, reflecting a mild stressful impact.\n Only 7.6% of participants had an IES score ?26. The majority of participants (53.3%) did not feel helpless due to the pandemic.\n On the other hand, 52.1% of participants felt horrified and apprehensive due to the pandemic.\n Additionally, the majority of participants (57.877.9%) received increased support from friends and family members, increased shared feeling and caring with family members and others.\n In conclusion, the COVID-19 pandemic was associated with mild stressful impact in our sample, even though the COVID-19 pandemic is still ongoing.\n These findings would need to be verified in larger population studies.\n","id":"PMC7177660","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"MDPI","authors":[{"firstname":"Yingfei","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zheng Feei","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Zheng Feei","surname":"Ma","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]},{"doi":"10.7150/ijbs.45221","date":"2020-02-28","title":"Knowledge, attitudes, and practices towards COVID-19 among Chinese residents during the rapid rise period of the COVID-19 outbreak: a quick online cross-sectional survey","abstract":"Unprecedented measures have been adopted to control the rapid spread of the ongoing COVID-19 epidemic in China.\n People's adherence to control measures is affected by their knowledge, attitudes, and practices (KAP) towards COVID-19. In this study, we investigated Chinese residents' KAP towards COVID-19 during the rapid rise period of the outbreak.\n An online sample of Chinese residents was successfully recruited via the authors' networks with residents and popular media in Hubei, China.\n A self-developed online KAP questionnaire was completed by the participants.\n The knowledge questionnaire consisted of 12 questions regarding the clinical characteristics and prevention of COVID-19. Assessments on residents' attitudes and practices towards COVID-19 included questions on confidence in winning the battle against COVID-19 and wearing masks when going out in recent days.\n Among the survey completers (n=6910), 65.7% were women, 63.5% held a bachelor degree or above, and 56.2% engaged in mental labor.\n The overall correct rate of the knowledge questionnaire was 90%.\n The majority of the respondents (97.1%) had confidence that China can win the battle against COVID-19. Nearly all of the participants (98.0%) wore masks when going out in recent days.\n In multiple logistic regression analyses, the COVID-19 knowledge score (OR: 0.75-0.90, P&lt;0.001) was significantly associated with a lower likelihood of negative attitudes and preventive practices towards COVID-2019. Most Chinese residents of a relatively high socioeconomic status, in particular women, are knowledgeable about COVID-19, hold optimistic attitudes, and have appropriate practices towards COVID-19. Health education programs aimed at improving COVID-19 knowledge are helpful for Chinese residents to hold optimistic attitudes and maintain appropriate practices.\n Due to the limited sample representativeness, we must be cautious when generalizing these findings to populations of a low socioeconomic status.\n","id":"PMC7098034","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Ivyspring International Publisher","authors":[{"firstname":"Bao-Liang","surname":"Zhong","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wei","surname":"Luo","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Hai-Mei","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Qian-Qian","surname":"Zhang","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Xiao-Ge","surname":"Liu","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Wen-Tian","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"},{"firstname":"Yi","surname":"Li","email":"NULL","contributions":"0"}]}]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.bbi.2020.04.069","date":"2020-04-25","title":"Do psychiatric patients experience more psychiatric symptoms during COVID-19 pandemic and lockdown? submaximal exercise","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fphys.2015.00405","date":"2015-12-10","title":"Correlates of Heart Rate Measures with Incidental Physical Activity and Cardiorespiratory Fitness in Overweight Female Workers","abstract":"Previous studies have suggested that physical activity (PA) levels and cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) impact on the autonomic control of heart rate (HR).\n However, previous studies evaluating PA levels did not discriminate between incidental PA and regular exercise.\n We hypothesized that incidental PA per se would influence cardiac autonomic indices as assessed via HR variability (HRV) and HR recovery (HRR) in non-exercisers.\n Thus, the objective of this study was to investigate the relationships between objective PA levels, CRF, and cardiac autonomic indices in adult, regular non-exercising female workers.\n After familiarization with procedures and evaluation of body composition, 21 women completed a submaximal cycling test and evaluation of HRR on four different days.\n Resting (2-min seated and standing) and ambulatory (4-h) HRV were also recorded.\n Levels of PA were assessed by accelerometry over five consecutive days (i.\ne.\n, Wednesday to Sunday).\n Maximum oxygen consumption (VO2max) was measured as an index of CRF.\n As reliability was low to moderate for most HR measures, relationships between these and PA and CRF were examined using the 4-day average measures.\n Significant correlations were identified between post-exercise HRR in the first min with various PA indices (daily moderate PA, daily vigorous PA, and the sum of vigorous and very vigorous daily PA).\n Additionally, VO2max was significantly correlated to HRV but not to HRR.\n The current results indicated that CRF was influential in enhancing HRV while incidental or non-exercise based PA was associated with greater autonomic reactivation in adult overweight women.\n Therefore, both CRF and non-exercise based PA contribute significant but diverse effects on cardiac health.\n The use of 4-day averages instead of single measures for evaluation of autonomic control of HR may provide a better indication of regular cardiac autonomic function that remains to be refined.\n","id":"PMC4704056","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Frontiers Media found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1136/bmjsem-2015-000036","date":"2015-10-15","title":"Exercise as medicinethe use of group medical visits to promote physical activity and treat chronic moderate depression: a preliminary 14-week prepost study","abstract":"Objective\nThe evidence that regular physical activity can treat depressive disorders is increasingly robust.\n\n However, motivating patients with depression to engage in physical activity can be challenging.\n\n Interdisciplinary group medical visits (GMVs) with an integrated physical activity component may be a novel means to support patients in becoming more active.\n\n\nMethods\nWe conducted a prepost pilot study within a primary care setting.\n\n Participants were adults (?18?years) with a chronic major depressive disorder or a bipolar 2 disorder (depression; chronic).\n\n A psychiatrist and exercise therapist co-led a series of 14 weekly 2?h GMVs.\n\n Each group visit combined specific medical advice, physical activity, patient discussions and a targeted educational component.\n\n Participants also attended 11 weekly hatha yoga classes.\n\n Primary outcome was steps as measured by accelerometer (SenseWear) as well as depression (Patient Health Questionnaire, PHQ-9) and anxiety (Generalised Anxiety Disorder, GAD-7) ratings.\n\n\nResults\n14 of 15 participants (93.3%) completed the 14-week programme.\n\n After 3?months postintervention, median depression scales (PHQ-9) decreased 38% from 16 to 10 (p&lt;0.01; IQR pre/post 8/12); and median anxiety scales (GAD-7) decreased 50% from 13 to 6.5 (p&lt;0.05; IQR 8.5/9).\n\n Median daily steps increased 71% from 3366 to 5746 (IQR 2610/6237), though this was not significant (p&gt;0.10).\n\n\nConclusions\nWhile other studies have examined the efficacy of GMVs in addressing chronic illnesses and the promotion of lifestyle changes, none to our knowledge have embedded physical activity within the actual patient visits.\n\n Interdisciplinary GMVs (eg, psychiatrist/exercise professional) may be a means to decrease depression and anxiety ratings within clinical care while improving physical activity.\n\n\n","id":"PMC5117054","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BMJ Publishing Group","authors":[{"firstname":"David men had a\nsignificantly better lipoprotein profile and antioxidant status, as well as reduced\noxidative damage and inflammatory state.\n The active young and elderly men had\nsignificantly higher a few studies have been performed in youth populations.\n\n Consequently, the main objective of this study was to examine the association between serum BDNF and a composite z-score consisting of six adolescents between 1117 years of age participated in this cross-sectional study.\n\n Cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF), anthropometrics, pubertal status, blood pressure (BP), serum BDNF, high-density Inflammation-related Depression and Potential Therapeutic Targets","abstract":"Depression is the most prevalent and among the most debilitating of psychiatric disorders.\n The precise neurobiology of this illness is unknown.\n Several lines of evidence suggest that peripheral and central inflammation plays a role in depressive symptoms, and that anti-inflammatory drugs can improve depressive symptoms in patients with inflammation-related depression.\n Signaling via brain-derived neurotrophic factor (BDNF) and its receptor, tropomycin receptor kinase B (TrkB) plays a key role in the pathophysiology of depression and in the therapeutic mechanisms of antidepressants.\n A recent paper showed that lipopolysaccharide (LPS)-induced inflammation gave rise to depression-like phenotype by altering BDNF-TrkB signaling in the prefrontal cortex, hippocampus, and nucleus accumbens, areas thought to be involved in the antidepressant effects of TrkB agonist, 7,8-dihydroxyflavone (7,8-DHF) and TrkB antagonist, ANA-12. Here we provide an overview of the tryptophan-kynurenine pathway and BDNF-TrkB signaling in the pathophysiology of inflammation-induced depression, and propose mechanistic actions for potential therapeutic agents.\n Additionally, the authors discuss the putative role of TrkB agonists and antagonists as novel therapeutic drugs for inflammation-related For older adults and special populations","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1479-5868-8-79","date":"2011-07-28","title":"How many steps/day are enough? for adults","abstract":"Physical activity guidelines from around the world are typically expressed in terms of frequency, duration, and intensity parameters.\n Objective monitoring using pedometers and accelerometers offers a new opportunity to measure and communicate physical activity in terms of steps/day.\n Various step-based versions or translations of physical activity guidelines are emerging, reflecting public interest in such guidance.\n However, there appears to be a wide discrepancy in the exact values that are being communicated.\n It makes sense that step-based recommendations should be harmonious with existing evidence-based public health guidelines that recognize that 'some physical activity is better than none' while maintaining a focus on time spent in moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA).\n Thus, the purpose of this review was to update our existing knowledge of 'How many steps/day are enough?', and to inform step-based recommendations consistent with current physical activity guidelines.\n Normative data indicate that healthy adults typically take between 4,000 and 18,000 steps/day, and that 10,000 steps/day is reasonable for this population, although there are notable 'low active populations.\n' Interventions demonstrate incremental increases on the order of 2,000-2,500 steps/day.\n The results of seven different controlled studies demonstrate that there is a strong relationship between cadence and intensity.\n Further, despite some inter-individual variation, 100 steps/minute represents a reasonable floor value indicative of moderate intensity walking.\n Multiplying this cadence by 30 minutes (i.\ne.\n, typical of a daily recommendation) produces a minimum of 3,000 steps that is best used as a heuristic (i.\ne.\n, guiding) value, but these steps must be taken over and above habitual activity levels to be a true expression of free-living steps/day that also includes recommendations for minimal amounts of time in MVPA.\n Computed steps/day translations of time in MVPA that also include estimates of habitual activity levels equate to 7,100 to 11,000 steps/day.\n A direct estimate of minimal amounts of MVPA accumulated in the course of objectively monitored free-living behaviour is 7,000-8,000 steps/day.\n A scale that spans a wide range of incremental increases in steps/day and is congruent with public health recognition that 'some physical activity is better than none,' yet still incorporates step-based translations of recommended amounts of time in MVPA may be useful in research and practice.\n The full range of users (researchers to practitioners to the general public) of objective monitoring instruments that provide step-based outputs require good reference data and evidence-based recommendations to be able to design effective health messages congruent with public health physical activity guidelines, guide behaviour change, and ultimately measure, track, and interpret steps/day.\n","id":"PMC3197470","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed occupational physical activity (OPA) does not confer the cardiovascular health benefits that leisure time physical activity does","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1371/journal.pone.0115894","date":"2014-11-09","title":"Physical Activity Patterns of People Affected by Depressive and Anxiety Disorders as Measured by Accelerometers: A Cross-Sectional Study","abstract":"Background\nExercise can relieve both depressive and anxiety disorders and it is therefore of importance to establish movement patterns of mildly to moderately affected sufferers to estimate the treatment potential.\n\n The aim is to describe the physical activity patterns of people affected by mild to moderate depressive and/or anxiety symptoms using objective measures of physical activity.\n\n\nMethods\nThe design of the study was cross-sectional using data from 165 people aged 1865 years, with mild to moderate depressive and/or anxiety disorder symptoms (scoring ?10 on the PHQ-9).\n\n Diagnoses were made using Mini International Neuropsychiatric Interview (MINI) and symptom severity was measured with the Montgomery-Åsberg Depression Rating Scale (MADRS).\n\n The participants wore accelerometers for a week to evaluate physical activity patterns.\n\n\nResults\nNo statistically significant differences were detected between different diagnoses, though depressed participants tended to be less active and more sedentary.\n\n Only one-fifth of the sample followed public health guidelines regarding physical activity.\n\n Each one point increase in MADRS was associated with a 2.4 minute reduction in light physical activity, independent of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity and sedentary time.\n\n MADRS was positively associated with number of sedentary bouts.\n\n\nConclusions\nThe physical activity pattern of people with depressive and/or anxiety disorders was characterized by large amounts of sedentary time and low fulfillment of physical activity guidelines.\n\n There is therefore a large treatment potential for this group by increasing exercise.\n\n The results suggest that instead of focusing exclusively on high intensity exercise for treating depressive and anxiety disorders, health care providers might encourage patients to reduce sedentary time by increasing light physical activity and decreasing the number of sedentary bouts, though further studies are needed that can determine directionality.\n\n\n","id":"PMC4293141","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of severity and quality of life at discharge in an inpatient cohort","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1016/j.eurpsy.2016.08.011","date":"1970-01-01","title":"Treatment guidelines for depression: greater emphasis on physical activity is needed","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.2196/10112","date":"2018-05-10","title":"Web-Based Intervention Using Behavioral Activation and Physical Activity for Adults With Depression (The eMotion Study): Pilot Randomized Controlled Trial","abstract":"Background\nPhysical activity is a potentially effective treatment for depression and depressive relapse.\n\n However, promoting physical activity in people with depression is challenging.\n\n Interventions informed by theory and evidence are therefore needed to support people with depression to become more physically active.\n\n eMotion is a Web-based intervention combining behavioral activation and physical activity promotion for people in the community with symptoms of depression.\n\n\nObjective\nThe objectives were to assess the feasibility and acceptability of delivering eMotion to people in the community with symptoms of depression and to explore outcomes.\n\n\nMethods\nParticipants with elevated depressive symptoms were recruited from the community through various methods (eg, social media) and randomized to eMotion or a waiting list control group for 8 weeks.\n\n eMotion is an administratively supported weekly modular program that helps people use key behavior change techniques (eg, graded tasks, action planning, and self-monitoring) to re-engage in routine, pleasurable, and necessary activities, with a focus on physical activities.\n\n Feasibility data were collected that included the following: recruitment and trial retention rates; fidelity of intervention delivery, receipt, and enactment; and acceptability of the intervention and data collection procedures.\n\n Data were collected for the primary (depression) and secondary outcomes (eg, anxiety, physical activity, fidelity, and client satisfaction) at baseline and 2 months postrandomization using self-reported Web-based questionnaires and accelerometers.\n\n Delivery fidelity (logins, modules accessed, time spent) was tracked using Web usage statistics.\n\n Exploratory analyses were conducted on the primary and secondary outcomes.\n\n\nResults\nOf the 183 people who contacted the research team, 62 were recruited and randomized.\n\n The mean baseline score was 14.6 (SD 3.2) on the 8-item Patient Health Questionnaire depression scale (PHQ-8).\n\n Of those randomized, 52 participants provided accelerometer-recorded physical activity data at baseline that showed a median of 35.8 (interquartile range [IQR] 0.0-98.6) minutes of moderate-to-vigorous physical activity (MVPA) recorded in at least 10-minute bouts per week, with only 13% (7/52) people achieving guideline levels (150 minutes of MVPA per week).\n\n In total, 81% (50/62) of participants provided follow-up data for the primary outcome (PHQ-8), but only 39% (24/62) provided follow-up accelerometer data.\n\n Within the intervention group, the median number of logins, modules accessed, and total minutes spent on eMotion was 3 (IQR 2.0-8.0), 3 (IQR 2.0-5.0), and 41.3 (IQR 18.9-90.4), respectively.\n\n Acceptability was mixed.\n\n Exploratory data analysis showed that PHQ-8 levels were lower for the intervention group than for the control group at 2 months postrandomization (adjusted mean difference ?3.6, 95% CI ?6.1 to ?1.1).\n\n\nConclusions\nIt was feasible to deliver eMotion in UK communities to inactive populations.\n\n eMotion has the potential to be effective and is ready for testing in a full-scale trial.\n\n Further work is needed to improve engagement with both the intervention and data collection procedures.\n\n\nTrial Registration\nClinicalTrials.\n\ngov NCT03084055; and (2) to ascertain whether training fidelity would influence these adaptations.\n One hundred and nine participants were divided into an experimental (EG) and control (CG) groups.\n The EG performed a SIT program that consisted of 6 sessions of 4 × 30 s all-out efforts on a cycle ergometer, interspersed with active rests of 4 min.\n The criterion for fidelity was achieving &gt;90% of estimated maximum heart rate (HR) during sprint bouts.\n After analyses, the EG was divided into HIGH (n = 26) and LOW (n = 46) fidelity groups.\n Components of attention were assessed using the Attention Network Test (ANT).\n Aerobic capacity (VO2max) was estimated while the sum of skinfolds was determined.\n Autonomic control of HR was assessed by means of HR variability (HRV) and HR complexity at rest and during ANT.\n Both HIGH and LOW significantly increased aerobic capacity, vagal modulation before and during ANT, and executive control, and decreased body fatness after SIT (p &lt; 0.05).\n However, only participants from HIGH showed an increase in HR complexity and accuracy in ANT when compared to LOW (p &lt; 0.05).\n Two weeks of SIT improved executive control, body fatness, aerobic fitness, and autonomic control in university students with better results reported in those individuals who exhibited high fidelity.\n","id":"PMC5871711","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Frontiers Media S.A.","authors":[{"firstname":"Arilson F. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpubh.2017.00312","date":"2017-11-06","title":"Diminution of Heart Rate Variability in Bipolar Depression","abstract":"Autonomic nervous system (ANS) dysregulation in depression is associated with symptoms associated with the ANS.\n The beat-to-beat pattern of heart rate defined as heart rate variability (HRV) provides a noninvasive portal to ANS function and has been proposed to represent a means of quantifying resting vagal tone.\n We quantified HRV in bipolar depressed (BDD) patients as a measure of ANS dysregulation seeking to establish HRV as a potential diagnostic and prognostic biomarker for treatment outcome.\n Forty-seven BDD patients were enrolled.\n They were randomized to receive either escitalopramcelecoxib or escitalopram-placebo over 8?weeks in a double-blind study design.\n Thirty-five patients completed the HRV studies.\n Thirty-six healthy subjects served as controls.\n HRV was assessed at pretreatment and end of study and compared with that of controls.\n HRV was quantified and corrected for artifacts using an algorithm that incorporates time and frequency domains to address non-stationarity of the beat-to-beat heart rate pattern.\n Baseline high frequency-HRV (i.\ne.\n, respiratory sinus arrhythmia) was lower in BDD patients than controls, although the difference did not reach significance.\n Baseline low-frequency HRV was significantly lower in BDD patients (ln4.20) than controls (ln?=?5.50) (p?&lt;?0.01).\n Baseline heart period was significantly shorter (i.\ne.\n, faster heart rate) in BDD patients than controls.\n No significant change in HRV parameters were detected over the course of the study with either treatment.\n These findings suggest that components of HRV may be diminished in BDD patients.\n","id":"PMC5723669","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Frontiers Media found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.3389/fpsyg.2014.00278","date":"2014-03-15","title":"From the heart to the mind: cardiac vagal tone modulates top-down and bottom-up visual perception and attention to emotional stimuli","abstract":"The neurovisceral integration model (Thayer and Lane, 2000) posits that cardiac vagal tone, indexed by heart rate variability (HRV), can indicate the functional integrity of the neural networks implicated in emotioncognition interactions.\n Our recent findings begin to disentangle how HRV is associated with both top-down and bottom-up cognitive processing of emotional stimuli.\n Higher resting HRV is associated with more adaptive and functional top-down and bottom-up cognitive modulation of emotional stimuli, which may facilitate effective emotion regulation.\n Conversely, lower resting HRV is associated with hyper-vigilant and maladaptive cognitive responses to emotional stimuli, which may impede emotion regulation.\n In the present paper, we recapitulate the neurovisceral integration model and review recent findings that shed light on the relationship between HRV and top-down and bottom-up visual perception and attention to emotional stimuli, which may play an important role in emotion regulation.\n Further implications of HRV on individual well-being and mental health are completed suicide.\n\n In this study we identify genes contributing to suicidal behaviour in the depression study RADIANT.\n\n\nMethodology/Principal Findings\nA quantitative suicidality score was composed of two items from the SCAN interview.\n\n In addition, the 251 depression cases with a history of serious suicide attempts were classified to form a discrete trait.\n\n The quantitative trait was correlated with younger onset of depression and number of episodes of depression, but not with gender.\n\n A genome-wide association study of 2,023 depression cases was performed to identify genes that may contribute to suicidal behaviour.\n\n Two Munich depression studies were used as replication cohorts to test the most strongly associated SNPs.\n\n No SNP was associated at genome-wide significance level.\n\n For the quantitative trait, evidence of association was detected at GFRA1, a receptor for the neurotrophin GDRA (p?=?2e-06).\n\n For the discrete trait of suicide attempt, SNPs in KIAA1244 and RGS18 attained p-values of &lt;5e-6. None of these SNPs showed evidence for replication in the additional cohorts tested.\n\n Candidate gene analysis provided some support for a polymorphism in NTRK2, which was previously associated with suicidality.\n\n\nConclusions/Significance\nThis study provides a genome-wide assessment of possible genetic contribution to suicidal behaviour in depression but indicates a genetic architecture of multiple genes with small effects.\n\n Large cohorts will be required to dissect this further.\n\n\n","id":"PMC3130038","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Public Library of during adolescence","abstract":"Unknown Abstract","id":"not found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.4103/0019-5545.42395","date":"1970-01-01","title":"BIS-11A -Hindi version: A preliminary study of impulsivity in rural and urban Indian adolescents","abstract":"Context:\nDespite of there being a pressing need to gauge impulsivity scores, there is no behavioral instrument in India to assess the impulsivity in adolescents.\n\n No earlier studies have been done in India to access impulsivity in adolescents.\n\n Even in western countries, no study has been done in rural setting to access impulsivity, although segment of rural population is small in western nations with major population residing in urban areas.\n\n\nAims:\nTo translate BIS-11A into Hindi from English in a culturally sensitive manner and to do preliminary study in rural and urban areas.\n\n\nSettings and Design:\nFirst translation of BIS-11 (as it is meant for adults) and cultural substitution resulted in Hindi adult version.\n\n Adolescent version was derived from adult version by replacing adult activities with adolescent activities.\n\n\nMaterials and Methods:\nBIS-11 English version was translated into Hindi and a back translation was made.\n\n As BIS-11 was developed for adults, answering some of the questions poses challenges for adolescents, so to be used with adolescents, questions that do not fit into adolescent age group were substituted keeping in view the activities of adolescents.\n\n Besides, questions that were not suitable as per the Indian culture were modified.\n\n Initially, these changes were made hypothetically by discussion among the authors and later a group of 48 school students were interviewed about the questions.\n\n Based on the interviews of students a final version was prepared.\n\n Translation, back translation, cultural substitution -hypothetically, and in school by discussion were carried out.\n\n The questionnaire was given to 120 urban high school students (in Jaipur, northern India) and 50 rural students (at Kanota, 25 km from Jaipur, northern India) and the scores were calculated as per the scoring method provided with original BIS-11.\nStatistical Analysis:\nT-test (two-tailed, two sample unequal variance, i.\n\ne.\n\n, type 3) was used.\n\n\nResults:\nT-test (two-tailed, two sample unequal variance, i.\n\ne.\n\n, type 3) found no significant difference between impulsivity scores of adolescents of urban and rural areas t 0.05(2)1 = 0.57, |t| &lt; t 0.05(2)1, P &gt; 0.05, P = 12.706. There were no gender related differences either.\n\n\nConclusions:\nAs impulsivity can lead to suicide and is implicated for substance abuse in disorders like Schizophrenia, it is important that culturally sensitive impulsivity studies are done in India on a large scale keeping in view the large size of population.\n\n Standardization of the BIS11-A Hindi version is being taken up.\n\n The work on Hindi version also generates necessity for other tasks if BIS-11(Hindi version) is to be used widely.\n\n Work on psychometric properties of Hindi version of BIS-11 A is being taken up.\n\n There is a need to devise a quick way to calculate impulsivity scores keeping in view the large population of India (1 billion out of which at least 33% is Hindi speaking, Census Survey of India, 2001).\n\n Besides, BIS-11A needs to be developed for other regional languages in India as there is a high-linguistic diversity in India.\n\n\n","id":"PMC2738344","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"Medknow Publications","authors":[{"firstname":"Paramjeet","surname":"Singh","email":"NULL","contributions":"1"},{"firstname":"R. found","idformat":"N/A","foundapis":"","miscinfo":"","authors":[]},{"doi":"10.1186/1743-8462-2-8","date":"2005-04-19","title":"Routine measurement of outcomes in Australia's public sector mental health services","abstract":"Objective\nThis paper describes the Australian experience to date with a national 'roll out' of routine outcome measurement in public sector mental health services.\n\n\nMethods\nConsultations were held with 123 stakeholders representing a range of roles.\n\n\nResults\nAustralia has made an impressive start to nationally implementing routine outcome measurement in mental health services, although it still has a long way to go.\n\n All States/Territories have established data collection systems, although some are more streamlined than others.\n\n Significant numbers of clinicians and managers have been trained in the use of routine outcome measures, and thought is now being given to ongoing training strategies.\n\n Outcome measurement is now occurring 'on the ground'; all States/Territories will be reporting data for 200304, and a number have been doing so for several years.\n\n Having said this, there is considerable variability regarding data coverage, completeness and compliance.\n\n Some States/Territories have gone to considerable lengths to 'embed' outcome measurement in day-to-day practice.\n\n To date, reporting of outcome data has largely been limited to reports profiling individual consumers and/or aggregate reports that focus on compliance and data quality issues, although a few States/Territories have begun to turn their attention to producing aggregate reports of consumers by clinician, team or service.\n\n\nConclusion\nRoutine outcome measurement is possible if it is supported by a co-ordinated, strategic approach and strong leadership, and there is commitment from clinicians and managers.\n\n The Australian experience can provide lessons for other countries.\n\n\n","id":"PMC1097711","idformat":"PMC","foundapis":"_PMC","miscinfo":"BioMed
